editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: OVID's ART OF LOVE;
IN THREE BOOKS:
TOGETHER WITH HIS REMEDY OF LOVE:
TRANSLATED INTO ENGLISH VERSE, By everal eminent Hands:
TO WHICH ARE ADDED, THE COURT OF LOVE, THE HISTORY OF LOVE, AND ARMSTRONG'S OECONOMY OF LOVE.
NEW-YORK Printed and old by SAMUEL CAMPBELL, No. 124, Pearl Street M,DCC,XCV.

div.head: TO THE RIGHT HONOURABLE RICHARD, EARL OF BURLINGTON.

lg.l: OUR Poet's rules, in eay numbers, tell
He felt the paion he decribes o well.
<> that oft art uccesfully refin'd
Tho' angry Caear frown'd, the fair were kind.
More ills from love, than tyrants' malice flow;
Jove's thunder trikes les ure than Cupid's bow.
Ovid both felt the pain, and found the eae;
Phyicians tudy mot their own dieae.
The practice of that age in this we try;
Ladies hould liten then, and lovers lie.
Each thought her own admirer in the right;
To be but faintly rude was criminal,
But to be boldly o, aton'd for all.
Breeding was banih'd for the fair one's ake;
The ex ne'er gives, but uffers ours hould take.
Advice to you, my Lord, in vain we bring.
The flow'rs ne'er fail to meet the blooming pring.
Tho' you poes all nature's gifts, take care;
Love's queen has charms, but fatal is her nare.
On all, that goddes her fale miles betows,
As on the eas he reigns, from whence he roe.
Young Zephyrs ing with fragrant breath, oft gales
Guide her gay barge, and well the ilken falls:
Each ilver wave in beauteous order moves,
Fair as her boom, gentle as her doves;
But he that once embarks, too urely finds
A ullen ky, black torms, and angry winds.
Cares, fears, and anguih, hov'ring on the coat,
And wrecks on wretches, by their folly lot.
When coming time hall bles you with a bride,
Let paion not peruade, but reaon guide:
Intead of gold, let gentle truth endear:
She has mot charms, who is the mot incere.
Shun vain variety, 'tis but dieae:
Weak appetites are ever hard to pleae.
The nymph mut fear to be inquiitive:
'Tis for the ex's quiet to believe.
Her air an eay confidence mut hew,
And hun to find, what he would dread to know
Still charming with all arts that can engage,
And be the JULIANA of the age.

div.head: INTRODUCTION.
div.p: OVID'S Art of Love, having lately appeared in French with Obervations written by the tranlator, which have been very well received in France; it has been thought proper to add uch of them as are mot curious to this verion, and to make other new remarks in ome places, where the Englih tranlators have given another turn to the original. The introduction to thee obervations is entirely the French author's; o are mot of the reflections. 'Tis hop'd thoe that are not taken from him, will not be found to be of les importance than thoe that are

A great many people are mitaken in thee books: and though they were made ue of as a pretence to drive the author from the court of Augutus, and confine him to Tomos, on the frontiers of the Getae and Surmatae, yet they were not the true caue of his confinement. They are very far from being o licentious as the writings of everal other poets, both Greek and Latin. However, we mut own he might have been a little more dicreet, epecially in ome places.

That which offended the Romans mot in this work, cannot touch us. It has always been more dangerous in Italy to convere with women of honour, and frequent their houes, than 'tis with us: Though there is more liberty, and what in that country may be an occaion of debauchery, would not at all be o in ours.

Notwithtanding all that has been aid againt thee books of the Art of Love, by ome over-crupulous perons, whoe dicretion has too much of affectation in <> ; they are not only neceary for the knowledge of the Latin tongue, and the Roman hitory, concerning which they contain everal things very particular; but for the noble <> we find in them, which the mot grave and <…> have thought worthy to be <…> .

In a word, there's nothing in them that comes near the licence of ome epigrams of Catullus Martial, and Auonius, of ome atyrs of Horace and Juvenal, and everal other pieces of ancient and modern authors which are read and commented upon; and about which even celebrated Jeuits and other religious perons, as eminent for their piety as their erudition, have employed their tudies. Yet who has condemn'd or complain'd of them? We mut confes, uch things hould be manag'd with addres: and thoe of them who have meddled with any of the authors I have named, have hewn that it may be done o, by their ucceeding o happily in it.

As for this treatie of the Art of Love, for which the author has alo precrib'd a remedy, as it is liable to be all interpreted by thoe whoe pens poion every thing they touch; o it may bear a good contruction, by uch as know how to turn every thing to advantage.

I will yet ay, this Art may be apply'd to thoe that intend to marry. There is nothing ure againt decency in all that. I agree, if you will have it o, that it extends o far as to direct one to the means to gain a mitres. If this was not lawful heretofore in Italy, on account of the jealous humour of the Italians, we cannot, for the ame reaon only, ay it ought to be forbidden in our country, any more than in everal others, provided we could be ure the ladies modety would not be offended, before whom youth hould be always careful not to exceed the bounds of the repect that's due to them.

Be it as it will, I have thought of endeavouring to apply all that is aid in thoe books of wanton love, to the art of loving the ciences. The emblem is not diagreeable, neither is it impoible to explain all that Ovid has written here upon the love of beauty by that of the arts. What do we not ometimes undertand by the loves of a hepherd and hepherdes? By a lover of incomparable beauty, and his fair one paionately in love? But, keeping to the fable, how often has the loves of Jupiter and
Juno been moraliz'd upon, as well as thoe of Apollo and Daphne, Mars and Venus, Myrrha and Cynaras, and everal others, the examples of which are almot infinite? Yet thee things are een every day, all the world read and admire them. Tho' the outide of them is a little trong, and the literal ene more upected, than any of the precepts laid down in Ovid's Art of Love are licentious.

But, to often this thought a little, let us figure to ourelves, that the poet is not only a gallant of the court of Augutus, but a philoopher of the Portic and Lyceum; who propoes to us, as to his diciples, excellent rules to acquire the virtues and ciences, repreented under the name of the mues, or ladies of various beauty, who may be met with every where, epecially in great academies, in the chools, in courts, in walks, and in holy places; figured by cirques, theatres, galleries, portices, and the temples of the Roman deities, where great aemblies were held. And when we have choen that which pleaes us bet, and is mot agreeable to our nature; let us endeavour to gain its good graces, and enjoy it, that we may become more wie, and more virtuous. Thus we may deceive our imagination: and 'twill be eay for us to make the reading of this treatie, not only pleaant, but profitable. We need not then have any cruple upon us, becaue there is nothing unchate in the expreion, though uch things as are entirely gallant are not neglected; at leat no farther than modety and decency requir'd. I will, if I can, explain my thoughts in this matter, according as occaion may offer.

Of the Art of Love. By this we ought to undertand how we mut love, or how we mut preerve the <> of our love, when we have once acquir'd it. Otherwie 'twas ueles to write an Art of love. For love is form'd in the heart without art, and all are without art uceptible of that paion. It generally urprizes us, and we know not from whence it comes, though we feel it very enibly. For this reaon the poets o often endeavour to
peruade us that love is a potent god, who wounds every thing with his darts; and that there is no creature able to reit him. We therefore need no art to teach us to love, or even to love any thing reaonably; but 'tis of very great importance to each of us, that, when we are inpir'd, the inpiration hould be for a proper object, and a good end, as I deign to hew you.

Ovid. This poet wrote thee books a few years before his exile, under colour of which the decree of the enate for his banihment was procur'd though they certainly were not the caue of it; and indeed could not reaonably be o, unles Ovid wrote them in favour of Augutus's granddaughter, whom he viited with a little too much familiarity, and did it to pleae her. For he, no more than her mother, Agrippa's wife, was not o modet as perons of quality and high condition ought to be, as well for their own glory, as for an example to others.

The two firt books of the Art of Love, contain the precepts which the author lays down for young men to follow in their courthip to the ladies, and the third teaches the ladies how they ought to make themelves belov'd. The allegory is not uneaily applied to the ciences and the virtues, repreented as lovely women, after my way of imagining it.

div.head: OVID's ART OF LOVE.

div.head: BOOK I.

lg.l: IN Cupid's chool, whoe'er would take degree,
Mut learn his rudiments, by reading me
Seamen with failing arts their veels move;
Art guides the chariot; a art intructs to love
Of hips and chariots, others know the rule;
But I am mater in love's mighty chool.
Cupid indeed is obtinate and wild.
A tubborn god b; but yet the god's a child:
Eay to govern in his tender age,
Like fierce Achilles in his pupilage.
That hero, born for conquet, c, trembling tood
Before the centaur, and receiv'd the rod. d
As Chiron e mollify'd his cruel mind
With art; and taught his warlike hands to wind
The ilver trings of his melodious lyre:
So love's fair goddes does my oul inpire
To teach her oftet arts; to ooth the mind,
And mooth the rugged breats of human kind.
Yet Cupid and Achilles, each with corn
And rage were fill'd; and both were goddes-born.
The bull, reclaim'd and yok'd, the burden draws:
The hore receives his bit within his jaws.
And tubborn love hall bend beneath my way,
Tho' truggling oft he trives to diobey.
He hakes his torch, he wounds me with his darts;
But vain his force, and vainer are his arts.
The more he burns my oul, or wounds my ight,
The more he teaches • o revenge the pite.
I boat no aid the Delphian god affords,
Nor aupice from the • light of chattering birds; h
Nor Clio nor her iters have I een,
As Heiod aw them on the hady green:
Experience makes any work a truth o try'd.

And if the hall itelf be not bely'd,
Even there the caue of love is often try'd.
Near it at leat, or in the palace yard;
From whence the noiy combatants are heard,
The crafty counellors, in formal gown,
There gain another's caue, but loe their own.
Their eloquence is non plus'd in the uit;
And lawyers, who had words at will, are mute.
Venus, from her adjoining temple, miles,
To ee them caught in their litigious wiles.
Grave enators lead home the youthful dame;
Returning clients, when they patrons came.
But above all, the play-houe is the place;
There's choice of quarry in that narrow chace.
There take thy tand, and harply looking out,
Soon may't thou find a mitres in the rout;
For length of time, or for a ingle bout.
The theatres are berries for the fair;
Like ants on mole-hills, thither they repair:
Like bees to hives, o num'rouly they throng,
It may be aid, they to that place belong.
Thither they warm, who have the public voice
There chue, if plenty not ditracts thy choice.
To ee, and to be een, in heaps they run;
Some to undo, and ome to be undone.
From Romulus the rie of plays began,
To his new ubjects a commodious man;
Who, his unmarried oldiers to upply,
Took care the commonwealth hould multiply:
Providing Sabine women for his braves:
Like a true king, to get a race of laves.
His play-houe, not of Parian marble made,
Nor was it pread with purple ails for hade.
The tage with ruhes, or with leaves they trew'd:

lg.l: <…> of homely, turf they at to ee,
Crown'd with the wreaths of every common tree
There, while they it in rutic majety,
Each lover had his mitres in his eye;
And whom he aw mot uiting to his mind,
For joys of matrimonial rape deign'd.
Scarce cou'd they wait the Plaudit in their hate;
But ere the dances and the ongs were pat,
The monarch gave the ignal from his throne:
And riing, bade his merry men fall on.
The martial crew, like oldiers ready pret,
Jut at the word (the word too was the bet)
With joyful cries each other animate;
Some chue, and ome at hazard eize their mate.
As doves from eagles, or from wolves the lambs,
So from their lawles lovers fly the dames.
Their fear was one, but not one face of fear;
Some rend the lovely trees of their hair:
Some hriek, and ome are truck with dumb depair.
Her abent mother one invokes in vain;
One tands amaz'd, not daring to complain;

But nought availing, all are captives led,
Trembling and bluhing, to the genial bed.
She who too long reited, or deny'd,
The luty lover made by force a bride;
And with uperior trength compell'd her to his •• le,
Then ooth'd her thus:—My oul's far better part,
Ceae weeping, nor afflict thy tender heart.
For what thy father to thy mother was,
That • aith to thee, that olemn vow I pas.
Thus Romulus became o popular;
Th •• was the way to thrive in peace or war.
To pay his army, and freh whores to bring:
Who would not • ight for uch a gracious king
Thus love in theatres did firt improve;
And <…> till the cene of love.
Nor hun the chariot's and the courer's race;
The t Circus is no inconvenient place.
No need is there of talking on the hand:
Nor nods, nor igns, which lovers undertand. u
But boldly next the fair your eat provide;
Cloe as you can to hers, and ide by ide.
Plea'd or unpleas'd no matter, crowding it,
For o the laws of public hews permit;
Then find occaion to begin dicoure
Enquire whoe chariot this, and whoe that hore;
To whatoever ide he is inclin'd,
Suit all your inclinations to her mind:
Like what he likes, from thence your court begin;
And whom he favours wih that he may win.
But when the tatues of the deities,
In chariots roll'd, appear before the prize;
When Venus comes, with deep devotion rie.
If dut be on her lap, or grains of and,
Bruh both away with your officious hand
If none be there, yet bruh that nothing thence;
And till to touch her lap make ome pretence.
Touch any thing of hers; and if her train
Sweep on the ground, let it not weep in vain;
But gently take it up, and wipe it clean
And, while you wipe it, with oberving eye,
Who knows what charming objects you may py?
Oberve who its behind her, and beware,
Let his encroaching knee hould pres the fair.
Light ervice takes light minds: for ome can tell
Of favours won by laying cuhions well.
By fanning faces ome their fortunes meet;
And ome by laying foottools for the feet.
Thee overtures of love the Circus gives:
Nor at the word-play les the lover thrives:
For there the on of Venus fights his prize
And deepet wounds are oft receiv'd from eyes.
One, while the crowd their acclamations ma •• ,
Or while he bets, and puts his ring to take,
Is truck from far, and feels the flying dart;
And of the pectacle is made a part.
Caear would repreent a naval fight, y
For his own honour, and for Rome's delight.
From either ea the youths and maidens come;
And all the world was then contain'd in Rome.
In this vat concoure, in this choice of game,
What Roman heart but felt a foreign flame?
Once more our prince prepares to make us glad;
And the remaining eat to Rome will add.
Rejoice ye Roman oldiers in your urn,
Your enigns from the Parthians hall return,
And the lain Crai hall no longer mourn.
A youth is ent thoe trophies to demand;
And bears his father's thunder in his hand:
Doubt not th' imperial boy in wars uneen,
In childhood all of Caear's race are men.
Celetial eeds hoot out before their day,
Prevent their years, and brook no dull delay.
Thus infant Hercules the nakes did pres;
And in his cradle did his • ire confes.
Bacchus, a boy, yet like a hero fought,
And early poils from conquer'd India brought.
Thus you your father's troops hall lead to fight,
And thus hall vanquih in your father's right.
Thee rudiments you to your lineage owe;
Born to increae your title as you grow.
Brethren you had, revenge your brethren lain;
You have a father, and his rights maintain.
Arm'd by your country's parent and your own,
Redeem your country and retore his throne.
Your enemies aert an impious came;
You • ight both for divine and human laws.
Already in their caue they are o'ercome;
Subject them too, by force of arms, to Rome.
Great father Mars with greater Caear join;
To give a prosp'rous Omen to your line;
One of you is, and one hall, be divine.
I prophecy you hall, you hall o'ercome:
My vere hall bring you back in triumph home.
Speak in my vere, exhort to loud alarms;
O were my numbers equal to your arms,
Then would I ing the Parthians' overthrow
Their hot a vere ent from a flying bow.
The Parthians, who already flying ight,
Already give an Omen of their flight,
O when will come the day, by heav'n deign'd,
When thou, the bet and fairet of mankind,
Drawn by white hores halt in triumph ride,
With conquer'd laves attending on thy ide,
Slaves, that no longer can be afe in flight?
O glorious object, O urpriing ight,
O day of public joy; too good to end in night!
On uch a day, if thou, and next to thee,
Some beauty it, the pectacle to ee;
If he enquire the names of conquer'd kings,
Of mountains, rivers, and their hidden prings,
Anwer to all thou knowet; and, if need be,
Of things unknown eem to peak knowingly:
This is Euphrates, crown'd with reeds; and there
Flows the wift Tigris with his ea-green hair. z
Invent new names of things unknown before;
Call this Amenia, that the C • pian hore:
Call this a Mede, and that a Parthian youth;
Talk probably no matter for the truth.
In feats, as at our hows, new means abound:
More pleaure there than that of wine is found.
The Paphian goddes there her ambuh lays;
And love betwixt the horns of Bacchus plays:
Deires increae at every welling draught:
Brik vapours add new vigour to the thought.
There Cupid's purple wings no flight afford;
But, wet with wine, he flutters on the board.
He hakes his pinions, but he cannot move;
Fix'd he remains, and turns a maudlin love.
Wine warms the blood, and makes the pirits flow;
Care flies, and wrinkles from the forehead go:
Exalts the poor, invigorates the weak;
Gives mirth and laughter, and a roy cheek.
Bold truths it peaks; and poken, dares maintain;
And brings our old implicity again.
Love parkles in the cup, and • ills it higher:
Wine feeds the flames, and fuel adds to fire.

But chue no mitres in thy drunken fit,
• a
Wine gilds too much their beauties and their wit.
Nor trut thy judgment when the tapers dance;
But ober, and by day, thy uit advance,
By day-light Paris judg'd the beauteous three;
And for the fairet did the prize decree.
Night is a cheat, and all deformities
Are bid, or leen'd in her dark diguie.
The un's fair light each error will confes,
In face, in hape, in jewels, and in dres.
Why name I ev'ry place where youth abound?
'Tis lo • s of time; and a too fruitful ground.
The Bajan baths bb where hips at anchor ride,
And wholeome treams from ulphur fountains glide
Where wounded youths are by experience taught,
The waters are les healthful than they thought.

That maiden goddes is love's mortal foe,
And much from her his ubjects undergo.

c Chiron. Ovid calls Philly rides, that is the son of Phillyra; for Chiron was the on of Phillyra, daughter of Oceanus and Saturn; who made love to her in the hape of a hore, according to Aratus.
d This alludes to the killing Hector.

p.U: ubmitted to the dicipline of the centaur Chiron; and when he had committed a fault, held out his hands to the Ferula, or rather rod for correction.

div.p: f Cupid was the on of Venus, and Achilles of Theis. Both were children alike, and both hard to govern. For indeed the paions of love and glory, are not eaily overcome by reaon, which ought always to be mitres.
g This is, (ays he) to hew us that love may always be tamed by habit.

h The poets, as is well known, always invoked this divinity; but Ovid's manner is here particular; he addrees Venus to be propitious to him, the ubject relating to that goddes. From whence the ancients drew their auguries. To which the poet here <> . As if
he would have aid, I am not Heiod, who, as he kept his flocks in the vale of Aera (that poet being a hepherd) aw the nine mues, who inpired him to make veres. The vale of Aera was at the foot of mount Helicon, where Dius and Lycemede, Heiod's father and mother dwelt.
i It has been before oberved, that he invokes the goddes of love to ait his ong.
k The poet here gives his advice as to three things; to eek after an amiable object; to win it by repect and complacency; and not to loe it after once gotten.
l Alluion to Paris, who ailed from Troy to Greece to look for a wife, where he tole the famous Helen, o much talked of, and carried her off.
m Generally interpreted, and is uppoed to mean the temple of concord, built by Livia, Cermanicus's mother.
n The Danaides, o called from their father Danaus, king of Argos; and ometimes Belides, from the name of their grandfather Belus, who had two ons, Egyptus and Danaus.

o It was the cutom among the Romans, to meet in the temple of Venus to mourn Adonis; of which the Prophet Ezekiel peaks, Ezek. viii. 14. Ovid means the temple of Venus, where that goddes was worhipped at Rome with Adonis, according to the manner of the Ayrians.

p There were a great number of the Jews at Rome, in Augutus's reign, who were allowed full liberty to exercie their ceremonies, according to the law of Moes And the Roman ladies went often to ee them out of curioity, which gave occaion for aignations at their Synagogues.

q This relates to certain ceremonies in the temple of Iis, after the manner of the Egyptians. He calls this •• mple the Cow of Nile. The feat of Iis was celebrated every year by the women ten days together, and
not without allowing themelves great liberty on thoe occaions.
r Many women were debauched by Iis's means, as he was by Jupiter under the name of Io, whoe • able all the world have heard of.

The idea of the Roman theatres in their infancy, may put us in mind of our own, which we read of in old poets in Bluckfryers, the Bull and mouth, and Barbican, not much better than the trollers at a country fair.

t Thee races were in the Cirque, or in the Hippodromes, or the field of Mars, and were commonly run in the month of April, in the grand Cirque, between the Aventine and Palantine hills. The word Circus, or Cirques, comes from the hores running round the coure o •
Metes.
u 'Tis plain by this the ancient Romans ued to make love by igns on their fingers, like the modern Spaniards and Portuguee.

x Amphitheatres, where the gladiators fought: Of which Juvenal peaks epecially in the 6th Satyr: He calls it Tritis Arena, on account of the murders that were committed there; and the Romans, with all their politenes, mut have a great mixture of cruelty in their tempers or they would not have taken pleaure in eeing men cut one another's throats, and look on with o much indifference, that they could make love in thoe very places.

y The naval combats were repreented in a place dug on purpoe on the banks of the Tiber; 'twas called Naumachia and, when occaion requir'd, the river water was et into it. This alludes to the triumphs of the Roman conquerors; They were wonderfully magnificent, accompanied with rich poils, and pictures of rivers, mountains, cities, and provinces conquered by them; not to peak of the captive kings and great captains that followed the victor's car in chains.
z A river that runs through Armenia, and fails in •• the Euphrates with a very rapid current.

aa. The poets gave horns to this god, to hew his malice and obtinacy, very well repreented by horns. This is Fe •• s's thought: and the ancients us'd to ay o of uch as were drunk. The night is an ill time to chue a mitres <> .

cc. The overeign priet of Diana, Aricina, called himelf king, and often got that dignity by gaining the better of hi • oponent in ingle combat. The wife of this-king-priet call'd herelf Queen of Sacrifices. He propoes here • he means to obtain the good graces of thoe we think worthy to be courted: And we mut do the ame to acquire fine learning, as lovers do to atisfy their paions; there is no need of more care, and the pleaure is much greater. oo 'Tis not eay to find out this propitious hour, epecially in the affairs of love, and, to ay truth, all depends on fortune, and certain conjectures that cannot be foreeen. Yet 'tis requiite a man hould do his utmot to <> out the lucky minute.

* The ancients ued to write on a ort of leaves or plants of everal kinds, plater'd over with wax, before the invention of paper was found out, at leat of uch paper as ours; for 'tis well known they had the leaves of a certain plant call'd Papyrus, which were brought from Egypt. 'Tis true the ancients had other ways of writing, as on kins called Chartae, and that comes nearer our paper; but our paper is of another pecies.

† That is, don't let your wit get the better of your paion; nor as a modern poet did, court your mitres with metaphyics. Avoid affected learning, too many figures, and in every thing that looks like art; for that is always upected in the affairs of love. Thoe who would write love letters, hould not eek after flourihes, nor ue ounding words.

Wine is favourable to lovers, inpiring them at once with boldnes and vigour.

uu The nuring father and pedagogue of Bacchus.

aaa Erythus, or Eurition, was one of the Centaurs at Pirithous's wedding, who o got drunk that he attempted to ravih Hippodamia the bride; but Theeus knock'd him down with a bowl, and made him bring his wine up again with blood.
bbb Modety is a vice when it hinders us from doing any thing that is profitable to us.
ccc He talks of modety, and ays, if the lover banihes it, he has no occaion for eloquence; for love and fortune favour the bold.
ddd Buiris, king of Egypt, on of Neptune and Lybia.

eee Phoebe and Ilara were two daughters of Leucippus, both famous for their beauty. Their father promis'd them in marriage to Idas and Lynceus, but Cator and Pollux tole them away from him. Idas and Lynceus puruing the ravihers, Cator fell by the hand of Lynceus, and Lynceus was himelf lain by Pollux: Idas running upon the latter, to revenge the death of his companion, was truck to the ground by thunder at Pollux's • eet.
fff Minerva or Pallas, was not only the goddes of arms, but of arts and manufactures.
ggg Orion fell in love with Lymne; but who he was is not well known.

on of Men • cius, and grandon of Actor, who having kill'd Clytonymus, on of Amphidamas, was banih'd his country, and came to Phia, where he remain'd with Peleus, Achilles's father, his kinman. By this means he contracted a trict friendhip with Achilles, and accompanied him to the iege of Troy, where he was killed. Hermione, daughter of Menelaus and Helen, who married her couin german Oretes. Pylades
was her huband's friend, and therefore he would not offer to corrupt his wife. This prince was the on of Strophius, king of Phocis.

div.p: iii A lover mut comport himelf variouly, according to the various humours of women.
kkk This gives us a various idea, and lively exprees, that women are to be caught everal ways.

lg.l: NOW Io Paean ing! new wreaths prepare!
And with repeated Ios fill the air:
The prey is fall'n in my uccesful toils,
My artful nets incloe the lovely poils.
My numbers now, ye miling lovers, crown,
And make your poet deathles in renown.
With lating ame my vere hall be inroll'd.
And I preferr'd to all the bards of old.
Thus Paris from the warlike Spartans bore
Their ravih'd bride, to Ida's ditant hore.
Victorious Pelops thus in triumph drove
The vanquih'd maid, and thus enjoy'd his love.
Stay, eager youth! your bark's but under ail;
The ditant port requires a prop'rous gale.
'Tis not enough the yielding beauty's found,
And with my aid your artful paion crown'd.
The conquets, our uccesful conduct gain'd,
With art mut be ecur'd, with art maintain'd.
The glory's more to guard than win the prize;
There all the • oil and threat'ning danger lies.
If ever, Cupid, now indulgent prove;
O Venus! aid; thou charming queen of love!
Kind Erato, let thy aupicious name
Inpire the work, and raie my gen'rous flame.
The labour's great; a method I deign
For love; and will the fetter'd god confine:
The god that roves the pacious world around,
In ev'ry clime, and ditant region found;
Active and light, his wings elude our guard,
And to confine a deity is hard.
His guet from flight Minos inclos'd around,
Yet he with wings a daring paage found.
Thus Daedalus her offspring firt confin'd,
Who, with a bull, in lewd embraces join'd:
Her teeming womb the horrid crime confes'd;
Big with a human bull, half man half beat.
Said he, jut Minos, bet of human kind,
The mercy let a protrate exile find.
By fates compell'd my native hores to fly,
Permit me, where I durt not live, to die.
Enlarge my on, if you neglect my tears.
And hew compaion to his blooming years:
Let not the youth a long confinement mourn,
O free the on, or let his ire return!
Thus he implor'd, but till implor'd in vain,
Nor could the freedom that he ought obtain.
Convinc'd at length; now Daedalus, he cry'd,
Here's ubject for thy art that's yet untry'd
Minos the earth commands, and guards the ea,
No pas the land affords, the deep no way;
Heav'n's only free, we'll heav'n's inpicious height
Attempt to pas, where kinder fates invite:
Favour, ye pow'rs above, my daring flight
Misfortunes oft prove to invention kind,
Intruct our wit, and aid the lab'ring mind.
For who can credit men in wild depair.
Should force a paage thro' the yielding air?
Feathers for wings deign'd the artit thoe,
And bound with thread his forming pinions cloe:
With temper'd wax the pointed ends he wrought,
And to perfection his new labours brought.
The finih'd wings his miling off-pring views,
Admires the work not concious of their ue:
To whom the father aid, oberve aright,
Oberve, my on, thee intruments of light.
In vain the tyrant our ecape retards,
The heav'ns he cannot, all but heav'n he guards:
Tho' earth and eas elude thy father's care,
Thee wings hall waft us thro' the pacious air.
Nor hall my on celetial igns urvey,
Far from the radiant virgin take your way;

Or where

the chilled north commands,
And with his falchion dread Orion tands:
I'll go before, me till retain in ight.
Where'er I lead, ecurely make your flight.
For hould we upward oar too near the un,
Diolv'd with heat, the liquid wax will run:
O • near the eas an humbler flight maintain,
Or <> will uffer by the treaming main.
A medium keep, the winds oberve aright;
The winds will aid your advantageous flight.
He caution'd thus, and thus inform'd him long,
As careful ••• ds intruct their tender young:
The preading wings then to his houlder bound,
His body pois'd and rais'd him from the ground.
Prepar'd for light, his aged arms embrace
The tender youth, whilt tears o'erflow his face
A hill there was, from whence the anxious pair
Eay'd their wings, and forth they launch'd in air.
Now his expanded plumes the artit plies,
Regards <> on, and leads along the kies:
Pleas'd with the novelty of light, the boy
Bounds in the air, and upward prings with joy
The angler views them from the ditant trand,
And quits • he labours of his trembling hand.

<>
they pat, and Na •• s in their light,
And Delos, with Apollo's preence bright.
Now on their right L • bynthos hores they found,
For fruitful lakes and hady groves renown'd.
When the apiring boy forgot his fears,
Rah with hot youth and unexperienc'd years:
Upwards he oar'd, maintain'd a luty troke,
And his directing father's way forook.
The wax, of heat impatient, melted run,
Nor could his wings utain that blaze of un.
From heav'n he views the fatal depths below,
Whilt killing fears prevent the ditant blow.
His truggling arms now no aitance find,
Nor poize the body, nor receive the wind.
Falling, his father he implores in vain,
To aid his flight, and inking limbs utain;
His name invokes, till the expiring ound
Far in the floods with Icarus was drown'd.
The parent mourns, a parent now no more,
And eeks the abent youth on ev'ry hore:
Where's my lov'd on, my Icarus! he cries;
Say in what ditant region of the kies,
Or faithles clime the youthful wand'rer flies!
Then view'd his pinions catter'd o'er the tream,
The hore his bones receiv'd, the waves his name.
Minos with walls attempted to detain
His flying guets, but did attempt in vain:
Yet the wing'd god hall to our rules ubmit,
And Cupid yield to more prevailing wit.
Thealian arts in vain rah lovers ue,
In vain with drugs the cornful maid abue:
The kilfull't potions ineffectual prove,
Ueles are magic remedies in love:
Could charms prevail, Circe had prov'd her art,
And fond Medea fix'd her Jaon's heart.
Nor tempt with philters the didainful dame;
They rage inpire, create a frantic flame:
Abtain from guilt, all vicious arts remove,
And make your paion worthy of her love.
Ditrut your empty form and boated face,
The nymph engage a thouand nobler ways.
To fix her vanquih'd heart entirely thine,
Accomplih'd graces to your nature join.
Beauty's but frail, a charm that oon decays,
Its lutre fades as rolling years increae,
And age till triumphs o'er the ruin'd face.
This truth the fair, but hort-liv'd lily hews,
And prickles that urvive the faded • o • e.
Learn, lovely boy, be with intruction wie!
Beauty and youth mi-pent are pat advice.
Then cultivate thy mind with wit and ame,
Thoe lating charms urvive the fun'ral flame.
With arts and ciences your breat improve,
Of high import are languages in love:
The fam'd Uyles was not fair nor young,
But eloquent and charming with his tongue:
And yet for him contending beauties trove,
And ev'ry ea-nymph ought the hero's love.
Calypo mourn'd when he forook her hores,
And with fond waves detain'd his haty oars.
Oft he inquir'd o • r ••• 'd Illum's fate,

Ditrut thy form, fond youth, and learn to know,

Make not your guilty mater's crime your own,

Indecent fury from her ight remove.
No paion let your mitres know, but love.
Yet if the haughty nymph's unkind, and coy,

By low degrees we bend the tubborn bough;

On his ubmiive neck her toils he wore,

Arm'd to the woods I bid you not repair,
Nor follow over hills the avage fair.
My oft injunctions les evere you'll find,
Eay to learn, and fram'd to ev'ry mind.
Her wihes never, nor her will withtand;
Submit, you conquer; erve, and you'll command.
Her words approve, deny what he denies,

Laugh when he miles; when ad, diolve in tears;

When he's at cards, or rattling dice he throws, d
Connive at cheats, and generouly loe.
A miling winner let the nymph remain,
Let your pleas'd mitres every conquert gain.
In heat, with an umbrella ready tand; e
When walking offer your officious hand:
Her trembling hands, tho' you utain the cold,
Cherih, and to your warmer boom hold.
Think no inferior office a digrace,
No action, that a mitres gains, is bae:
The hero that eluded Juno's pight,
And ev'ry monter overcame in ight;
That pat o many bloody labours o'er,
And well deerv'd that heav'n whoe weight be bore; f
Amidt Ionian damels carding tands,

In all commands the haughty dame obeys:
And who didains to act like Hercules?
If he's at law, be ure commend the laws,

With patience at the aignation wait,
Early appear, attend her coming late.
Whene'er he wants a meenger, away,
And her commands with flying feet obey.
When late from upper he's returning home,

She for the country air retires from town,
You want a coach, or hore, why foot it down:
Let not the ultry eaon of the year,
The falling nows, or contant rains deter.
Love is a warfare, and ignoble loth
<…> are watchings, duels, anxious cares,
The oldier thus, and thus the lover fares;
With rain he's drench'd with piercing tempet hakes,
And on the cooler earth his lodging takes.
Fame ays that Phoebus kept Admetus's herd; h
And <> in an humble cottage far'd:
Learn this y • lovers, and renounce your pride.
When all acces is to your mitres hard,

Thee arts will teach the tubborn beauty love.
Be cautious, let you over-act your part,
And temper your hypocriy with art:
Let no fale action give your words the lie,
For once deceiv'd he's ever after hy.
In Autumn oft, when the luxurious year
Purples the grape and hews the vintage near;
When ultry heats, when colder blats arie,
And bodies languih with incontant kies:
If vicious heav'n infects her tender veins,
And in her tainted blood ome fever reigns;
Then your kind vows, your pious care betow,
The bleings you expect to reap, then ow.
Think nothing naueous in her loath'd dieae,
But with your ready hand contrive to pleae:
Weep in her ight, then fonder kies give,
And let her burning lips your tears receive,
Much for her afety vow but louder peak,
Let the nymph hear the lavih vows you make.
As health returns o let your joys appear,
Oft mile with hope, and oft confes your fear.
This in her breat remains, thee pleaing charms
Secure a paage to her grateful arms.
Reach nothing naueous to her tate or ight,
Officious only when you mot delight:
Nor bitter draughts, not hated med'cines give:
Let her from rivals what he loaths receive.
Thoe prop'rous winds that launch'd our bark from hore,
When out at ea, aits its coure no more;
Time will your knowledge in our art improve,
Give trength and vigour to your forming love.
The dreadful bull was but a calf when young; o
The lofty oak but from an acorn prung:
From narrow prings the noblet currents flow,
But well their • lood and pread them as they go.
Be converant with love, no toils refue,
And conquer all fatigues with frequent ue.
Still let her hear your ighs, your paion view,
And night and day the flying maid purue.
Then paue awhile; by fallow fields we gain;
A thirty oil receives the welcome rain.
Phyllis was calm while with Demophoon bles'd,
His abence wounded mot her raging breat:
Thus his chate conort for Ulyes burn'd,
And Laodamia thus her abent huband mourn'd.
With peed return, you're ruin'd by delays,
Some happy youth may oon upply your place.
When Sparta's prince was from his Helen gone, p
Could Helen be content to he alone?
She in his bed receiv'd her am'rous guet,
And nightly clap'd him to her panting breat:
Unthinking cuckold, to a proverb blind!
What, trut a beau and a fair wife behind!
Let furious hawks thy trembling turtles keep,
And to the mountain wolves commit thy heep:
Helen is guiltles, and her lover's crime
But what yourelf would act another time.
The youth was preing, the dull huband gone,
Let ev'ry woman make the cae her own:
Who cou'd a prince, by Venus ent, refue?
The cuckold's negligence is her excue.
But not the foaming boar whom pears urround,
Revenging on the do •• his mortal wound.
Nor liones, whoe young receives the breat.
Nor drunkard by th' Aonian god poet, q
Trancend the woman's rage, by fury led,
To find a rival in her injur'd bed.
With •• re and word he flies, the frantic dame
Didains the thought of tendernes or hame.

Her offspring's blood enrag'd

pilt.r
A cruel mother, for the father's guilt.
And <> unrelenting fury proves.
That <> revenge purues neglected <> .
Where acred ties of honour are detroy'd,
Such errors cautious lovers mut avoid.
Think not my precepts contancy enjoin,
Venus avert! far nobler's my deign.
At large enjoy, conceal your paion well,
Nor ue the modih vanity to tell:
Avoid preenting of upected toys,
Nor to an hour confine your vary'd joys:
Deert the hades you did frequent before,
Nor make them concious of a new amour.
The nymph, when he betrays, didains your guilt,
And by uch fal • hood taught, he learns to jilt.
While with a wife Artid • s liv'd content, t
Their loves were mutual, and he innocent:
But when enflam'd with ev'ry charming face,
Her lewdnes till maintain'd an equal pace.
Chryes, as ame had told her, pray'd in vain,
Nor could by gifts his captive girl obtain;
Mournful Brieis, thy complaints he heard,
And how his lut the tedious war deferr'd.
This tamely heard but with reentment view'd,
The victor by his beauteous lave ubdu'd:
With rage he aw her own neglected charms,
And took AEgithus to her injur'd arms. u
To lut and hame by his example led,
Who durt o openly profane her bed.
What you conceal, her more oberving eye
Perhaps betrays; with oaths the fact deny,
And boldly give her jealouy the lie:
Not too ubmiive eem, nor over kind;
Thee are the ymptoms of a guilty mind:
But no carees, no endearments pare,
Enjoyment pacifies the angry fair.
There are, that trong provoking potions praie,
And nature with •••• tions med'cine raie.
Nor drugs, nor herbs will what you fancy prove,
And I pronounce them pois'nous all in love.
Some pepper bruis'd, with eeds of nettles join,
And clary teep in bowls of mellow wine: x
Venus is mot avere to forc'd delights,
Extorted flames pollute her genial rites.
With fihes pawn thy feeble nerves recruit,
And with eringo's hot alacious root.
The goddes worhip'd by th' Erycian wains,
Megara's white hallot, o faint, didains. y
New eggs they take, and honey's liquid juice, z
And leaves and apples of the pine infue.
Precribe no more, my mue, nor med'cines give,
Beauty and youth need no provocative.
You that conceal'd your ecret crimes before,
Proclaim them now, now publih each amour.
Nor tax me with incontancy; we find
The driving bark requires a veering wind:
Now northern blats we court, now outhern gales;
And ev'ry point befriends our hifted ails.
Thus chariot-drivers, with a lowing rein
Direct their teeds, then curb them in again.
Indulgence oft corrupts the faithles dame,
Secure from rivals he neglects your flame.
The mind without variety is cloy'd,
And naueates pleaures it has long enjoy'd.
But as a ire, whoe wated trength declines,
Converts to ahes, and but faintly hines;
When ulphur's brought, the preading flames return,
And growing embers with freh fury burn:
A rival thus th' ungrateful maid reclaims,
Revive deire, and feeds her dying flames.
Oft make her jealous, give your fondnes o'er,
And • eaze her often with ome new amour.
Happy, thrice happy youth, with pleaures blet.
Too great, <> to be expret

That view <>
• he anguih of her jealous breat.
Whene'er thy guilt the lighted beauty knows,
She woons; her voice, and then her colour goes,
Oft would my furious nymph, in burning rage,
Then how he'd weep, what piercing glances cat!
And vow to hate the perjur'd wretch at lat.
Let not your mitres long your falhood mourn:
Neglected fondnes will to fury turn,
But kindly clap her in your arms again,
And on your breat her drooping head utain;
Whilt weeping, kis, amidt her tears enjoy,
And with exces of blis her rage detroy.
Let her a while lament, a while complain,
Then die with pleaure as he dy'd with pain.
Enjoyment cures her with its powerful charms,
She'll igh a pardon in your active arms.
First nature lay an undigeted mas,
Heav'n, earth and ocean wore one common <>
Then vaulted heav'n was fram'd, waves <>
The beats inhabit woods, the birds the air,
And to their floods the caly fry repair.
Mankind alone enjoy'd no certain place,
On rapin liv'd, a rude unpolih'd race:
Caves were their houes, herbs their food and bed,
Whilt each a avage from the other led.
Love firt diarm'd the fiercenes of their mind,
And in one bed the men and woman <>
The youth was eager but <> in joy,
Nor was the unexperienc'd <> :
They knew no courthip, no intructor <>
Yet they enjoy'd and blet the pleaing wound.
The birds with conorts propagate their kind,
And porting fih their finny beauties find;
In am'rous • olds the wanton <>

And dogs with their <> female
<>
The luty bull delights his friking dames,
And more lacivious goat her male inflames.
Mares furious grow with love, their bound'ries force,
Plunging thro' waves to meet the neighing hore.
Go on, brave youth, thy gen'rous vigour try,
To the reenting maid this charm apply:
Loves oft'ning pleaures ev'ry grief remove,
There's nothing that can make your peace like love.
From drugs and philters no redres you'll find,
But nature with your mitres will be kind.
The love that's uncontrain'd will long endure,
Machaon's art was fale, but mine is ure. aa
Whilt thus I ung, inflam'd with nobler fire,
I heard the great Apollo's tuneful lyre:
His hand a branch of preading laurel bore,
And on his head a laurel wreath he wore;
Around he cat diffuive rays of light,
Confeing all the god to human ight.
Thou mater of lacivious arts, he aid,
To my frequented • ane thy pupils lead:
And there, incrib'd in characters of gold,
This celebrated entence you'll behold,
Firt know yourelf; who to himelf is known, bb
Shall love with conduct, and his wihes crown.
Where nature has a handome face betow'd,
Or graceful hape, let both be often hew'd:
Let men of wit and humour ilence hun,
The artit ing, and oldier bluter on:
Of long harangues ye eloquent take heed,
Nor thy damn'd works thou teazing poet read.
Thus Phoebus pa • e: A jut obedience give,
And thee injunctions from a god receive.
I myteries unfold; to my advice
Attend, ye vulgar lovers, and grow wie,
The thriving grain in harvet often ails,
Oft prop'rous winds turn advere to our ails:
Few are the pleaures, though the toils are great;
With patience mut ubmiive lovers wait.
What hares on Athos, bees on Hybla feed, cc
Or berries on the circling ivy breed;
As hells on andy hores, as tars above,
So num'rous are the ure fatigues of love,
The lady's gone abroad, you're told; tho' een,
Ditrut your eyes, believe her not within.
Her lodgings on the promis'd night are cloe,
Reent it not, but on the earth repoe,
Her maid will cry with an inulting tone,
What makes you aunter here? you ot begone.
With moving words the cruel nymph intreat;
And place your garland on the bolted gate.
Why do I light and vulgar precepts ue?
A nobler ubject now inpires my mue?
Approaching joys I ing, ye youths draw near,
Liten ye happy lovers and give ear:
The labour's great, and daring is my ong,
Labours and great attempts to love belong.
As from the acred oracles of Jove.
Receive thee grand myterious truths in love.
Look down when he the ogling park invites,
Nor touch the concious tablets when he writes,
Appear not jealous, tho' he's much from home,
Let her at pleaure go, unquetion'd come.
This crafty hubands to their wives permit,
And learn, when he's engag'd to wink at it.
I <> own <> modetly confes;
And <> , give thoe precepts I trangres.
Shall I, with patience the known ignal hear,
<> , and leave a happy rival there.
What <> uffer the provoking wrong,
I, like a fury, for my nymph engage,
And like a madman, when I mis her, rage.
My paion till preva •• s, convinc'd I yield:
He that ubmits to this is better kill'd.
Expoe not, tho' you find her guilty flame,
Let he abandon modety and hame:
Conceal her faults, no ecret crimes upbraid;
Nothing's o fond as a upected maid.
Dicover'd love increaes with depair.
• hen both alike the guilt and candal hare;
All ene of modety they loe in time,
While each encourages the other's crime.
In heav'n this tory's fam'd above the ret,
Among th' immortal drolis a tanding jet:
How Vulcan two trangreing lovers caught,
And ev'ry god a pleas'd pectator brought.
Great Mars for Venus felt a guilty flame,
Neglected war, and own'd a lover's name:
To his deires the queen of love inclin'd;
No nymph in heav'n's o willing, none more kind.
Oft the lacivious fair, with cornful pride,
Would Vulcan's foot and footy hands deride:
Yet both with decency their paion bore,
And modety conceal'd the cloe amour.
But by the un betray'd in their embrace,
(For what ecapes the un's oberving rays?)
He told th' affronted god of his digrace.
Ah, foolih un: and much unkill'd in love:
Thou hat an ill example for above.
Never a fair offending nymph betray
She'll gratefully oblige you ev'ry way:
The crafty poue around her bed prepares
A <> they <> , th' impatient lovers met, dd
And naked were expos'd to Vulcan's net.
The gods deride the criminals in chains,
And carce from tears the queen of love refrains:
Nor could her hands conceal her guilty face,
She wants that cover for another place.
To urly Mars a gay pectator aid,
Why o uneay in that envy'd bed?
On me transfer your chains; I'll freely come
For your releae, and uffer in your room.
At length, kind Neptune, freed by thy deires,
Mars goes to Crete, to Paphos he retires, ee
Their love augmented by revengeful fires,
Now converant with infamy and hame,
They et no bounds to their licentious flame.
But honet Vulcan, what was thy pretence
To act o much unlike a god of ene?
They in in public, you the hame repent,
Convinc'd that loves increae with punihment.
Tho' in your pow'r, a rival ne'er expoe;
Never his intercepted joys dicloe: ff
This I command, Venus commands the ame,
Who hates the nares he once utain'd with hame.
What impious wretch will Ceres' rites expoe? gg
Or Juno's olemn myteries dicloe?
His witty torments Tantalus deerves, hh
That thirts in waves, and viewing banquets tarves.
But Venus mot in ecrecy delights;
Away, ye babblers, from her ilent rites!
No pomp her myteries attend, no noie,
No ounding bras proclaims their late •• joys!
With folded arms the happy pair poes,
Nor hould the fond betraying tongue confes
Thoe raptures, which no language can expres.
When naked Venus cats her robes aide,
The parts obcure her hands extended hide:
No girl on propagating beats will gaze,
But hangs her head and turns away her face.
We darken'd beds and doors for love provide;
What nature cannot, decent habits hide:
Love darknes courts, at mot a glimm'ring light,
To raie our joys, and jut oblige the ight.
E'er happy men beneath the roof were laid,
When oaks provided them with food and hade;
Some gloomy cave receiv'd the wanton pair;
For light too modet, and unhaded air.
From public view they decently retir'd,
And ecretly perform'd what love inpir'd.
Now carce a modih fop about the town,
But boats with whom, how often, and where done;
They tate no pleaure, relih no delight,
Till they recount what pas'd the happy night.
But men of honour always thought it bae,
To protitute each kinder nymph's embrace;
To blat her fame, and vainly hurt his own,
And furnih candal for a lewd lampoon.
And here I mut ome guilty arts accue,
And diingenuous hifts that lovers ue,
To wrong the chate, and innocence abue.
When long repuls'd they find their courthip vain,
Her character with infamy they tain:
Deny'd her peron, they debauch her ame,
And brand her innocence with public hame.
Go, jealous fool, the injur'd beauty guard,
Let ev'ry door be lock'd, and window barr'd!
The uff'ring nymph remains expos'd to wrong.
Her name's a protitute to ev'ry tongue;
For malice will with joy the lie receive,
Report, and what it wihes true, believe.
With care conceal whate'er defects you find:
To all her faults eem like a lover blind.
Naked Andromeda when Pereus view'd,
He aw her faults, but yet pronounc'd them good.
Andromache was tall, yet ome report,
Her Hector was o blind he thought her hort.
At firt what's naueous leens by degrees.
Young loves are nice, and difficult to pleae.
The infant plant that bears a tender rind,
Reels to and fro with ev'ry breath of wind:
But hooting upwards to a tree at lat,
It tems the torm, and braves the tronget blat.
Time will defects and blemihes endear,
And make them lovely to your eyes appear:
Unuual cents at firt may give offence;
Time reconciles them to the vanquih'd ene.
Her vices often with ome kinder phrae;
If he is warthy as the negro's face, ii
Call it a graceful brown, and that complexion praie:
The ruddy las mut be like Venus fair,
Or like Minerva that has yellow hair.
If pale and meagre, praie her hape and youth,
Active when mall, when gros he's plump and mooth.
Ev'ry exces by oft'ning terms diguie,
And in ome neighb'ring virtue hide each vice.
Nor ak her age, conult no regiter,
Under whoe reign he's born, or what's the year
If fading youth chequers her hair with white,
Experience makes her perfect in delight;
In her embrace ublimer joys are found,
A fruitful oil, and cultivated ground!
The hours enjoy whilt youth and pleaure lat,
Age hurries on, and death purues too fat:
Or plough the eas, or cultivate the land,
Or wield the word in thy advent'rous hand;
Or much in love thy nervous trength employ,
Embrace the fair, the grateful maid enjoy;
Pleaures and wealth reward thy pleaing pains,
The labour's great, but greater far thy gains.
Ad • their experience in affairs of love,
For years and practice do alike improve;
Their a • ts repair the injuries of time,
And till preerve them in their charming prime;
In vary'd ways they act the pleaure o'er,
Not pictur'd potures can improve you more. kk
They want no courthip to provoke delight,
But meet your warmth with equal appetite:
Give me enjoyment when the willing dame ll
Glows with deires, and burns with equal flame.
I love to hear the oft tranporting joys,
The frequent ighs, and tender murm'ring voice:
To ee her eyes with vary'd pleaure move,
And all the nymph confes the pow'r of love.
Nature's not thus indulgent to the young,
Thee joys alone to riper years belong.
Who youth enjoys drinks crude unready wine,
Let age your girl, and prightly juice refine,
Mellow their weets, and make the tate divine.
To Helen who'd Hermione prefer?
Or Gorge think beyond her mother fair?
But he that covets the experienc'd dame
Shall crown his joys, and triumph in his flame.
One concious bed receives the happy pair:
Retire, my mue; the door demands thy care. mm
What charming words, what tender things are aid!
What language flows without thy ueles aid!
There hall the roving hand employment find,
Inpire new flames, and make ev'n virgins kind.
Thus Hector did Andromache delight,
Hector in love victorious as in ight.
When weary from the field Achilles came,
Thus with delays he rais'd Brie • s' flame.
Ah, could thoe arms, thoe fatal hands delight?
Inpire kind thoughts, and raie the appetite?
Couldt thou, fond maid, be charm'd with his embrace,
Stain'd with the blood of half thy royal race?
Nor yet with peed the fleeting pleaure wa • e,
Still moderate your love's impetuous hate:
The bahful virgin, tho' appearing coy,
Detains your hand, and hugs the proferr'd joy.
Then view her eyes with humid lutre bright,
Sparkling with rage, and trembling with delight.
Her kind complaints, her melting accents hear,
The eye he charms, and wounds the lit'ning ear.
Defer not then the claping nymph's embrace,
But with her love maintain an equal pace:
Raie to her heights the tranports of your oul,
And fly united to the happy goal,
Oberve thee precepts when with leiure blet,
No threat'ning fears your private hours molet;
When danger's near, your active force employ,
And urge with eager peed the haty joy.
Then ply your oars, then practie this advice.
And train with whip and pur to gain the prize.
The work's compleat, triumphant palms prepare,
With flow'ry wreaths adorn thy flowing hair.
As to the Greeks was Podalirius' art,
To heal with medicines the afflicted part:
Netor's advice, Achilles arms in field,
Automedon for chariot-driving kill'd;
As Calchas could explain the mytic bird, nn
And Telamon could wield the brandih'd word:
Such to the town may • am'd intructions prove,
So much I am renown'd for arts of love.
Me ev'ry youth hall praie, extol my name,
And o'er the globe diffue my lating fame.
I arms provide againt the cornful fair,
Thus Vulcan arm'd Achilles for the war.
Whatever youth hall with my aid o'ercome,
And lead his Amazon in triumph home; oo
Let him that conquers, and enjoy the dame,
In gratitude for his intructed flame,
Incribe the poils with my aupicious name.
The tender girls my precepts next demand,
Them I commit to a more kilful hand.

i This has alluion to a fetival celebrated at Rome by the ervants, in remembrance of a great piece of ervice their predeceors had done, the Romans, oon after the invaion of the Gauls; the time of celebrating it was in July.

m Indeed what Ovid complains of in his time, may with much more reaon be complained againt now; for the mues are not only neglected but depis'd. 'Tis too true, that learning of all orts is not in that eteem which it was in Augutus's days; and if there are few men who write good books, there are fewer till who read them.

n They curl'd their hair with a bodkin, and ometimes with a hot iron, as in our days; but they hew'd more of it, than 'tis the fahion of our modern ladies. The next care Ovid recommends to the lover, is the complaiance he is to oberve towards his mitres when he is ick. Alluding to a ceremony practis'd by the Romans of purifying the bed; an office which belonged to the nure. And this was done with ulphur and eggs; a ort of religious worhip, when vows were made of the health and ret of the patient.
o This and the following imilies are taken from country affairs, which have an agreeable effect on this occaion, when the poet peaks of the tendency of every living thing to love.
p Meneloeus was then abent in Crete, whether he and his brother Agamemnon went to divide the etate left them by their father Arteus.

q Aonia is taken here for
<> , of which Thebes was the capital, where Bacchus was born; and the fury
that tranports people when they are drunk, is very well compar • d to that of wild beats and vipers.

s Wife of Terens, king of Thrace, who killed her own daughters, and preented them to her huband, becaue he had ravihed her iter Philomena.

div.p: u AEgithus, the on of Thyetes and Pelopeia, his own daughter, killed his uncle Atreus, and his on Agamemnon, whoe wife Clytemnetra he had debauched, and was himelf killed by her on Oretes, to revenge the death of Agamemnon, his father.
x The quality of this plant is very hot, according to the everal obervations of Diocoriodes, and his commentator Mathiolus. As for the pepper its nature is hot and dry.

y Mount Eryx in Sicilly, was o called from Eryx, a on of Venus, who having taken a certain king called Burras to her arms, had this child by him. He built a temple here to his mother, when he arrived to man's etate, who from thence had the name of Erycinian, or Erycian: We have made bold to ue the word Erycian or Erye for the ake of the meaure.

z Here Ovid certainly peaks of a bulbous plant that grew in the territory of M • gara, which was of a hot quality and provocative. Alo hen and partridge eggs. The kernel of the pine apple and pi • achos are mentioned by the author, as provocative, and Pliny oberves, they trengthen the reins.

aa An admirable phyician, of whom Homer peaks in the 2d Iliad. And Diodora writes, that E •• mpius left two ons, who were both phyicians, and as famous as himelf, Machaon and
<> , who accompany' •
Agamemnon to the iege of Troy, and cured wounds almot to a miracle.

bb This was a aying of Chilo the Lacedoemonian, who was one of the even wie men of Greece. Pliny mentions him; and this aying was o highly eteem'd that 'twas written in letters of gold in the temple at Delphos

cc Athos is a mountain in Macedonia, or Thrace, according to Stephanus, which Xerxes, as Pliny tells us, divided 1500 paces from the continent; 'tis o high, that its top is above the region of the clouds.

dd Lemnos; as the poet ays, an iland in the AEgean ea, over againt mount Athos, according to Pliny. Phoetia and Myrine were two cities in it, in ancient times, whither, during the oltice, the mountain ued to end its hade.
ee Paphos is a city in Cyprus, conecrated to Venus.

ff He means intercepting a rival's letter, and dicovering the contents. To intercept letters, and divulge a ecret, was a crime punihable by the laws, by banihment, or interdiction of fire and water, by which was undertood exile.
gg This is a imile, and hews us, 'twas not lawful to reveal the myteres of Ceres.

hh He proves by the example of Tantalus, that no man hould reveal ecrets. Tantalus, o Diadorus tells us, was the on of Jupiter and the nymph Plato, equally rich and renown'd. Ere in return you write, ome time require;

How have I een the puzzled over vex'd,

Let not your pocket-book two hands contain;

Now, greater things to tell, my mue, prepare,

lg.l: Look in your glas when you with anger glow,

How have I een ome airs digut create,

l.hi: Like things which by antipathy we hate!

lg.l: Let looks with looks, and miles with miles be paid,

So, love precluding, plays at firt with hearts,

Nor me a melancholy mitres charms;

Let mournful beauties ullen heroes move;
We cheerful men like gaiety in love.
Let Hector in Andromache delight,

Had they not both borne children (to be plain)

I no idea in my mind can frame,

• our ev'ral lovers hould elect,

The wealthy lover tore of gold hould end;

We who write vere with vere alone hould bribe;

No fraud the poet's acred breat can bear,

Too faithfully, alas! we know to love;
With eae we fix, but we with pain remove;
Our ofter tudies with our ouls combine,

Be gentle, virgins, to the poet's pray'r,
The god that fills him, and the mue revere; nn
Something divine is in us, and from heav'n
Th' inpiring pirit can alone be giv'n.
'Tis in a price from poets to exact;
But 'tis a in no woman fears to act.
Yet hide, howe'er, your avarice from ight,

As kilful riders rein, with diff'rent force,
• o you by diff'rent management engage

This, while the wiles of love are yet unknown,
Will gladly cleave to you and you alone;

Alone, thus bles'd, of rivals mot beware:

l.hi: Nor love nor empire can a partner bear,

lg.l: Men more dicreetly love when they're mature
No windows break, no houes et on fire,

In youth, the boiling blood gives fury vent,

As wood when green, or as a torch when wet,
They lowly burn, but long retain their heat:
More bright is youthful flame, but ooner dies;
Then wiftly eize the joy that wiftly dies.
Thus, all betraying to the beauteous foe,

To trut a traitor, you'll no cruple make,

Who yields too oon, will oon her lover loe;
Would you retain him long? then long refue.
Oft at your door make him for entrance wait,
There let him lie, and threaten and intreat.
When cloy'd with weets, bitters the tate retore;
Ships by fair winds are ometimes run ahore.
Hence prings the coldnes of a marry'd life,
The huband, when he pleaes, has his wife.
Bar but your gate, and let your porter cry,
"Here's no admittance, Sir; I mut deny:" oo
The very huband, o repuls'd, will find

Thus far with foils you've fought; thoe laid aide,
I now harp weapons for the ex provide;

When firt a lover you deign to charm,

Make him believe, with all the kill you can,

Anon, by due degrees, mall doubt create,

Such little arts make love its vigour hold,

Then trains the courer to out-trip the wind,

Love, when extinct, upicions may revive;
I own, when mine's ecure 'tis carce alive.
Yet, one precaution to this rule belongs;

Sometimes, your lover to excite the more.
Pretends your huband's pies beet the door;

For, eeming danger heightens the delight.
Oft let the youth in thro' your windows teal;

And, ometimes, let your maid urprie pretend,

Yet, ever and anon, dipel his fear,

Let, quite dihearten'd with too much fatigue,

But I forgot to tell, how may you try
Both to evade the huband, and the py.
That wives hould of their hubands tand in awe,
Agree with jutice, modety, and law,
But, that a mitres may be lawful prize,

For uch fair nymphs, thee precepts are deign'd,

Tho' tuck with Argus' eyes your keeper were, qq
Advis'd by me, you will elude his care.
When you, to wah or bathe retire from ight,

Yet, thee perceiv'd, you may her back undres,

New milk, or pointed pires of flax, when green, rr

Acriius was, with all his care betray'd;

Can pies avail, when you to plays reort,

Tho watchful ervants to the bagnio come,

Once, I remember, I with caue complain'd

Believe me, apprehenions of that kind,

Perpetual fondnes of your lover feign,

Full of himelf, he your deign will aid!
To what we wih, tis eay to peruade,

Scarce o himelf will be forbear to cry,

Proud of the homage to his merit done.

Now to purue our voyage we mut provide,

You may expect, perhaps, I now hould teach

Come not the firt invited to a feat;

Beides, complexions of a coarer kind,

I own, I think, of wine the moderate ue

a Agamemnon and Menelaus, two brothers, married two iters, Clytemnetra and Helena, daughters of Tyu

b Eriphyle, daughter of Talaon, queen of Argos and wife of Amphiarus, being covetous of a gold chain, which Venus had given Hermione, and which Polynice's wife had received as a preent from that unfortunate prince, he gave it her on condition he obliged her huband to go to the Theban war, in which he knew he would perih; and he prevailed with him to go. This princes being thus the occaion of her huband's death, is often repreented as an intance of the falhood and vanity of the ex.

She married Capaneus, who ignalized himelf in the Theban war, of which the poet peaks here.

h Phyllis, daughter of Lycurgus king of Thrace, depairing for the return of Demophoon on of Thescus to whom he had granted her lat favours, was about to hang herelf; when, as the fable ays, the gods in compaion to her, turned her to an almond-tree without leaves: Demophoon, ometime after this, returning w • nt and embraced his metamorphoed mitres, and the <> afterwards put forth leaves, nine times, to hew that he as often went to the ea-ide, expecting to meet him. P The capitol was a hill in Rome, o called from a man's head which was found there as the Romans were digging the foundation of the temple of Jupiter. Varro writes, there were two orts of courts in the capitol; one for the deliberating acred matters, and the other for affairs of tate.

r By this we perceive the Roman ladies were as fond of fahions as the French <> Englih, too much their imitators.

s Iole, daughter of Eurytus, king of occhalla, and Hercules's wife. He took her from her father by force, becaue the king would not conent to it. When he returned from AEtolia, where he had marry'd Dejanira

t Pliny oberves, that women rarely hed their hair, eunuchs not at all; and no body, if we may believe him, neither on the hind part of the heads, nor about their temples and ears; for there is no animal that turns bald, except man.

v They dy'd their hair with the juice of herbs, according to the fahions of the Germans, who make ue of certain herbs to black their hair, or dye them of any colour, to diguie their age, and appear young.

x He was the on of Athamas, king of Thebes; and to avoid the anger of Ino, his mother-in-law, fled with his iter Hele upon a ram with a golden fleece. His iter tumbling into the ea, gave it the name of Hellepont; but he arriving at Chalcos, acrificed the ram to Mars, who plac'd it in the zodiac, and hung up his golden fleece in the temple conecrating it to Mars under the keeping of the dragon.

y Caucaus, is a mountain which tretches itelf from the Eat-Indies to mount Taurus, and goes by everal names, according as 'tis inhabited by everal nations; but being always covered with now in ome places, 'tis called Caucaus, which in the oriental ignifies white, as Ptolemy witneeth.

aa The Sidonian Europa, daughter of Agenor, king of Phoenicia, whom Jupiter fell in love with, and ravihed her in the hape of a bull: He carry'd her to Crete, and he there brought him three ons, Minos, Radamanthus, and Sarpedon. After that Aterius having no children, marry'd her, adopted Jupiter's ons, and left his kingdom to them, as Diodorus informs us. Europa is called the Sidonian, from the city of Sidon, built by the Phoenicians.

bb Pharos was a little iland at the mouth of the Nile. near the port of Alexandria, where anciently tood a tately high tower, reckoned one of the even wonders of the world. div.p: zz Every one has heard of Apelles, the famous painter. He was a native of Cos, or as others write Epheus: for his great kill in his art he was called the prince of painters.

aaa Perhaps there never was, and never will be an age, where ome poets, and thoe not the wort, will not have caue to complain with Ovid; who lived in a time when poetry was favoured with the protection, and honoured with the example of Augutus M • cenas, and the Roman court.

bbb Homer's name, and the contention of even cities for him, are o well known that there's no need of aying much about it; he was o called from his blindnes. He was the mot famous of all the Greek poets, but poor to the extremity of begging.

ccc Danoe, daughter of Acriius king of Argos; who having conulted the oracle, and being told that he hould be killed by her on, hut her up in a brazer, tower to prevent it. But Jupiter, transforming himelf into a golden hower, blinded her keepers, and got her with child; which, being born, was the renowned <> : her father commanded both the babe and his mother to be thrown into the ea; but being fortunately cat ahore on one of the ilands called Cyclades, the king of the iland marry'd the mother: and
<>
when he was grown up, unwittingly killed his grandfather.

ddd She was the daughter of Cepheus; king of Arcadia, and for her mother's pride, in comparing her beauty to that of Ne • ides, was expoed to a horrible ea monter, from whom he was delivered by the above named Pereus.

eee Priam, king of Troy, and father of Paris, who tole Helen, was for retoring her to the Greeks when they demanded her by their ambaadors; but other councils prevailing, the war enued, which ended in the detruction of Troy, and the death of Priam, who was killed by Py ••• us, on of Achilles, after 40 years reign.

fff The Nardus or Nard, was a plant brought from
<> , or Spira, from which a precious ointment was extracted, and put to the ame ues as the modern Beaux and Belles do their eences.

hhh Theeus's incontancy to Ariadne has rendered him famous among the incontants in tory.
iii This is very delicate, and hews of what importance 'tis for beauty to be well-bred, if it would be victorious.

kkk Minerva playing on her flute by a river ide, and eeing in the water what grimaces •• obliged her to make, he lung away the intrument in a paion, and curt it o much, that he who made ue of it afterwards had caue to repent of it.

mmm Nemeis was the goddes of jutice. The Romans involved her before they went to battle, and returned her thanks after victory, for revenging them on their enemies.

qqq The able of Argus has been poken of before: he had a hundred eyes, and kept Io from Jupiter by Juno's orders; for which Mercury killed him by command of his father Jove. To make him amends, Juno turn'd him into a peacock, and plac'd-his eyes in the tail.

xxx The prietees and priets of Bacchus, who celebrated the fetival of that god, did it with the noie of houts, drums, timbrels and cymbals, were crowned with ivy, vine, &c. and carried a Thryus or taff weav'd with it in their hands: they were frantic and outrageous in their actions during this ceremony.

zzz The reader has now gone thro' the Art of Love, and 'tis hoped he has found nothing to hock him. He <> look upon this book as a hitory of the manners and
cutoms of the ancients, not to imitate them, but ee Ovid's fine entiments, his eloquence, and fruitful invention, which makes him peak agreeably of every thing.

aaaa We ee Ovid made no cruple of calling him Nao, tho' it was a name of ditinction given him from his great noe, but perhaps not a name of contempt, great noes being more a beauty among the Romans than in our times.

div.head: OVID's REMEDY OF LOVE.

lg.l: THE title of this book when Cupid py'd.
Treaon! a plot againt our tate! he cry'd. b
Why hould you thus your loyal poet wrong,
Who in your war has erv'd o well and long!
So avage and ill-bred I ne'er can prove,
Like Diomedes, to wound the queen of love, c
Others by <> have felt your am'rous flame,
I till have been, and till your martyr am;
Rules for your vot'ries I did late impart,
Refining paion, and made love an art.
Nor do I now, of that of thee take leave,
Nor does the mue her former with unweave.
Let him, who loves where love ucces may find,
Spread all his ails before the prop'rous wind;
But let poor youths, who female corn endure,
And hopeles burn, repair to me for cure:
For why hould any worthy youth detroy
Himelf, becaue ome worthles nymph <>
Love hould be nature's friend; let hemp and teel
Hangmen and heroes ue, whoe trades to <> .
Where fatal it would prove, let paion ceae:
Nor love detroy, which hould our <>
A child you are, and like a child you play;
And gentle as your ears hould be your way.
Keen arrows, and to wound the hardet hearts,
You are permitted—but no mortal darts.
Let your tep father Mars, on word and pear d
The crimon tains of cruel conquet wear;
You hould your mother's milder laws oberve,
Who ne'er did childles parent's cure deerve.
Or if you mut employ your wanton pow'r,
Teach youths by night to force their mitres'd door:
How lovers afe and ecretly may meet,
And ubtle wives the cautious huband cheat:
Let now th' excluded youth the gate cares,
A thouand wheedling oothing plaints expres;
Then on th' ill-natur'd timber vent her pight,
And to ome doleful tune weep out the night.
For tears, not blood, love's altar hould require:
Love's torch, deign'd to kindle kind deire,
Mut eem profane, to light a fun'ral fire.
Thus I.—The god his purple wings diplay'd,
And, forward, finih your deign, he aid.
To me, ye injur'd youths, for help repair,
Who hopeles languih for ome cruel fair:
I'll now unteach the art I taught before,
The hand that wounded hall your health retore.
One oil can herbs and pois'nous weeds dicloe,
The nettle oft is neighbour to the roe.
Such was the cure th' Arcadian, hero found, e
The Pelian pear, that wounded, made him ound.
But know, the rules that I to men precribe,
In like ditres may erve the female tribe:
And when beyond your phere my methods go
You may, at leat, infer what you hould do.
When flames beyond their ueful bounds apire,
'Tis charity to quench the threatning fire.

Nor had Demophoon when return'd from ea,
For his expected bride, embrac'd a tree.
Nor Dido, from her flaming pile, by night.
Dicover'd her ungrateful Trojan's flight.
Nor had that mother dire revenge puru'd,

Nor Phoedra uffer'd by incetuous fire.
Let me the wanton Paris take in hand,
