lg.l: My wholeome precepts had lewd Scylla read,
The purple lock had grown on Nius' head.
Learn, youths, from me to curb the dep'rate force
Of love; and teer, by my advice your coure.
By reading me, you firt receiv'd your bane;
Now, for an antidote, read me again;
From cornful beauty's chains I'll et you free.
Conent but you to your own liberty.
<> , thou god of phyic and of vere, f
Ait the healing numbers I reheare;
Direct at once my med'cines and my ong,
For to thy care both provinces belong.
While the oft paion plays about your heart,
I fare the tickling venom turns to mart,
Break then (for then you may) the treach'rous dart:
<> up the eeds of the unrooted ill,
<> they are weak, and you have pow'r to kill.
<> delay; the tender bladed grain,
<> up to talk, can tand the wind and rain.
The tree, whoe branches now are grown too big

<>
• a • d, to bend, was et a lender twig:
When planted, to your lightet touch 'twould yield,
But now has fix'd poeion of the field,
confiding, ere to love you give the reins.
<> mitres worth your future pain •
While yet in breath, ere yet your nerves are broke,
Cat from your gen'rous neck the hameful yoke:
Check love's firt ymptoms, the weak foe urprie,
Who, once entrench'd will all your arts depie.
Think, wretch, what you hereafter mut endure,
What certain toil, for an uncertain cure.
Slip not one minute; who prefers to-day,
To-morrow will be harden'd in delay.
'Tis love's old practice, till to ooth you on,
'Tis your dieae gets trength, and till your trength is gone.
Rivers mall fountains have, and yet we find
Vat ets of thoe mall fountain'd rivers join'd,
Lock'd up in bark poor Myrr • a ne'er had been,
Had he the progres, of her crime foreeen;
But pleas'd with the oft kindling of love's fire,
We, day by day, indulge the fond deire;
'Till like a erpent it has eat its way,
And uncontroul'd does on her entrails prey.
Yet if the proper eaon you have pas'd,
Though hard the tak, I'll ue my kill at lat;
Nor ee my patient perih by his grief,
Becaue no ooner call'd to his relief.
When Philoctetus firt receiv'd his wound, g
The venom'd part cut off, had av'd the ound:
Yet he, ev'n after tedious years of grief,
Was cur'd, and brought the fainting Greeks relief
Thus I, who charg'd you peedy means to ue,
Will none, in lat extremities, refue.
Or try to quench the kindling flames, or tay
'Till their pent fury on itelf does prey.
While in its full career, give cope to rage.
And circumvent the force you can't engage.
What pilot would againt the current trive,
When with a ide-coure he may afely drive
Ditemper'd minds, ditracted with their grief,
Take all for foes, who offer them relief.
But when the firt fermenting mart is o'er,
They uffer you to probe the ripen'd ore.
'Tis madnes a fond mother to diuade
From tears, while on his heare her on is laid:
But when grief's deluge can no higher well,
Declining orrow you'll with eae repel.
Cures have their times; the bet that can be try'd
Enflame the wound, uneas'nably apply'd.
If therefore you expect to find redres,
In the firt place, take leave of idlenes. h
'Tis this that kindled firt your fond deire,
'Tis this brings fuel to the am'rous fire.
Bar idlenes, you ruin Cupid's game,
You blunt his arrows, and you quench his flame.
What wine to plane-trees, treams to poplars prove,
Marhes to reeds, is idlenes to love.
Mind buines, if your paion you'd detroy;
Secure is he, who can himelf employ.
Sleep, drinking, gaming, for the foe make way,
And to love's ambucade the roving heart betray.
The lothful he eeks out, and makes his prize,
Surely as he the man of buines flies.
Make buines (no matter what) your care;
Some dear friend's caue may want you at the bar:
Or if your courage tempts you to the field,
Love's wanton arms to rough campaigns will yield.
Parthia freh work for triumph does afford,
Half-conquer'd to your hand, by Caear's word.
Cupid's and Parthian darts at once o'ercome,
And to your country's gods bring double trophies home.
Your word as dreadful will to love appear,
As to his mother the AEtolian pear.
Th' adult'rous • ut that did AEgithus eize, i
And brought on murder, prang from wanton eae:
For he the only lo • te • er remain'd
At home, when Troy's long war the ret had drain'd.
He revell'd then at his luxurious board,
And ne'er embark'd and ne'er unheath'd his word:
But while the Grecians did for glory rove,
He wated all his idle hours in love.
Or country-work and tillage can diarm
Your am'rous cares, for ev'ry grief a charm.
Yoke oxen, plough the painful field, you'll find
The wounded earth will cure your love-ick mind;
Then trut your grain to the new-furrow'd oil,
That with large int'ret will requite your toil.
Behold what kind returns your fruit-trees end,
Down to your hand the burden'd branches bend.
Behold a murm'ring brook thro' patures glide,
Behold the grazing heep on either ide;
While in the hade, his pipe the hepherd tries,
The watchful dog his mater's care upplies.
With loud complaints another grove is fill'd
Of heifers lowing for their firtlings kill'd.
What pleaure 'tis with moke of yew to drive
The murm'ring warm, and eize the loaded hive.
All eaons friendly to the wain are found;
Autumn with fruit, with harvet ummer's crown'd;
The pring's adorn'd with flow'rs to charm the eye,
And winter fires the abent un upply.
At certain times you'll ee the vintage full,
And for your wine-pres may choice cluters cull.
At certain times you pond'rous heaves may bind,
Yet for the rake leave work enough behind.
The thirty you from neighb'ring prings may eed.
Then, grafting, make old tocks prout freh and green,
And various fruits on one proud branch be een
When once thee pleaures have your mind poet
Love oon departs, like a neglected guet.
Hunt, if the dull ditemper you'd remove:

<>
will too hard for Venus prove.
Thro' all her doubling hifts the hare purue,
O • pread your toils upon the mountain's brow.
Ev'n when the tag's at bay provoke his rage;
Or with the pear the foaming boar engage.
Thus tir'd, your ret at night will prove o deep,
Dreams of your mitres ne'er will haunt your leep.
'Tis eaier work, yet 't will require more care,
The feather'd game with bird-lime to ennare;
Or ele to fih your bearded hook to bait.
And for your art's ucces with patience wait
Thro' ports like thee you'll teal into relief,
And while your time you cozen, cheat your grief.
Or travel; (tho' you find your fetters trong)
Set out betimes; your journey mut be long.
You'd weep at thought of her you left behind,
And halting, to return be oft inclin'd.
But how much more unwilling to proceed,
Compel your feet to o much greater peed.
Advance, let nothing interrupt your way,
No wind nor weather, nor unlucky day.
Nor count the miles you've pat, but what remain;
For <> nigh no fond pretences feign.
Nor reckon time, nor once look back to Rome,
But fly; and Parthian like, by flight o'ercome.
You'll call my precepts hard; I grant they are:
<> for dear health who would not hardhips bear.
When ick, the bitter portion I have ta'en;
And for the fond I fancy'd begg'd in vain.
Both teel and fire you'll patiently endure,
And thirt more corching, for the body's cure.
<> you, who thus your earthly part redeem,
For your immortal mind have les eteem?
Yet, for my patient's comfort. I mut own,
When <> firt tage he manfully has run,
<> half, the wort half of his tak is done.
Gall'd with the yoke, at firt the heifer draws:
The curb's firt trial frets the courer's jaws.
Perhaps to leave your father's houe you'll mourn;
Yet go; and think, when tempted to return,
Your kindred but the fale pretence is made;
'Tis abence from your mitres does peruade.
When once et out, diverions you will meet,
Fair country propects, and companions weet.
Nor only travel far, but tarry long;
Nor once look homeward while your paion's trong.
Rebellious love, if he perceive your halt,
With greater fury will renew th' aault.
Half-famih'd paion will more fiercely prey,
And all your labour pat be thrown away.
You'll think, when thro' Hoemonian fields you rove, k
The magic arts may yield a cure for love.
Old tales of witchcraft trange effects reheare:
The only charm I bring is acred vere.
By my advice, no jargon hall be read,
Nor midnight hag, blapheming, raie the dead;
Nor tanding crop to other fields hall range;
No ick eclipe the un's complection change.
Old Tyber hall his acred coure retain,
And Cynthia, unmoleted, guide her wain.
No uff'ring heart to pells hall be oblig'd.
No love reign, by ulphur treams beieg'd.
Think on Medea of all hopes bereft.
When fled from home, and by her lover left.
And what did <> pow'rful drugs avail, l
When he beheld Ulyes under ail?
She try'd her magic, charm on charm renew'd;

No force or kill the fatal dart removes;
She raves to find he loves—but till he loves.
To thouand hapes he could transform mankind,

In thee oft terms, to her departing guet,

Think, till the thought your indignation move,

Your <> on thee topics hould be pent,

A certain nymph did once my heart incline,

(I, your phyician, my dieae confes)
I from my own precriptions found redres.
Her till I repreented to my mind,

How low of tatute! (yet the nymph was tall.)
Oh for what cotly preents will he call!

Such <> good and ill divide,

Ev'n truth, and your own judgment, you mut train,

lg.l: Cenure her free dicoure as confidence:
Her ilence, want of breeding and good ene.
Dicover her blind ide, and put her till
Upon the talk which he performs but ill.
Court her to ing, if he wants voice and ear;
To dance, if he has neither hape nor air;
If talking mibecomes her, make her talk:
If walking, then in malice make her walk;
Commend her kill when on the lute he plays,
Till vanity her want of kill betrays.
Take care, if her large breats offend your eyes,
No dres do that deformity diguie.
Ply her with merry tales of what you will,
To keep her laughing, if her teeth are ill.
Or if blear-ey'd, ome tragic tory find,
'Till he has read and wept herelf quite blind.
But one effectual method you may take,
Enter her chamber, e'er he's well awake:
Her beauty's art; gems, gold, and rich attire,
Make up the pageant you o much admire;
In all that pacious figure which you ee,
The leat, leat part of her own elf is he.
In vain for her you love, amidt uch cot,
You earch; the mitres in the dres is lot.
Take her dirob'd, her real elf urprie,
I'll trut you then, for cure, to your own eyes,
(Yet have I known this very rule to fail,
And beauty mot, when tript of art, prevail.)
Steal to her cloet, her cloe 'tiring place,

All colours of the rainbow you'll dicern,
Wahes and paints, and what you're ick to learn.
I now hould treat of what may pall deire,

(For all advantages you ought to make,
And arms from love's own magazine to take:)
But modety forbids at full extent

Which, to prevent your bluhes, I hall leave

For ome of late cenoriouly accue,

lg.l: No place is there for love and dalliance found.
The tragic tile requires a tale ditret,
And comedy conits of mirth and jet.
The tender elegy is love's delight,
Which to themelves pleas'd mitrees recite,
Callimachus would do Achilles wrong;
Cydippe were no theme for Homer's ong.
What mortal patience could endure to ee
Thais preenting chate Andromache?
Kind Thais, (none of Vetas's nuns) upplies p
My ong; with Thais all my bus'nes lies:
The actres, if my mue performs with art,
You mut commend, tho' you dilike the part,
Burt envy; I've already got a name;
And, writing more, hall more advance my fame
Depair not then, for as I longer live,
Each day freh fuel for your pleen hall give.
Thus fame's increaing gale bears me on high,
While tir'd and grovelling on the ground you lie,

Cenure did us to this digreion force;
Now, mue, purue thy intercepted coure.
When firt <> nymph admits your viit, tay,
And take ome other beauty in your way;
More afely thus your paion you may trut,
When you approach her charms with fainter gut:
You'll otherwie micontrue, for delight,
The eagernes of your own appetite.
Deire does all; the Grotto's cool retreat,
And hady grove, relieve in ummer's heat;
Warm fires in winter: Thirt makes water weet.
Now is the time, your artifice to try,
Act not o much the lover as the py:
For vanity makes all the fair preume
There's nothing which their charms can mibecome.
Take this occaion her defects to find,
When you can fix them deeper in your mind:
In the dull minute of your dicontents,
(The penive mood when ated love repents)
To your ick thoughts her blemihes diplay,
And, for averion, by thoe means make way.
Thee helps you'll ay are trivial; I confes,
Singly they are, but join'd will have ucces.
By one mall viper's bite an ox is kill'd; q
The foret boar by a les dog is held.
Unite my precepts, if apart they fail,
And by reitles number you'll prevail.
But diff'rent minds for diff'rent methods call,
Nor what cures mot, will have effect on all.
Ev'n that which makes another's flame expire,
Perhaps may prove but fuel to your fire.
For one, diguted with the nymph's undres,
Grows cold, and weary of her warm cares.
Another from his wanton mitres flies
When he his rival's recent raptures pies.
Like warm deire! And he but little loves,
Whom ev'ry trifle hocks, and nothing moves
To thoe I write, (for my advice they need)
Whoe hardy paion can unbaulk'd <>
What think you of that lover, who could lie
Conceal'd, to ee what cutom mut <>
I to no uch undecent means direct,

If to exces you find your paion rie,
I wou'd, at once, two mitrees advie. r
Divided care will give your mind relief;
What nourih'd one, may tarve the twins of grief,
Large rivers, drain'd in many treams, grow dry:
Withdraw its fuel, and the flame will die.
What hip can afely with one anchor ride?

If treated ill by her whom you adore,

A gentle cure is what I recommend;

'Twas on this core the fierce Achilles wept;

Good caue to weep, the maiden toy was got,

The poet had the better hero made.

Swore by his ceptre; nor can that eem odd;
He knew his ceptre but a wooden god.
O could you once arrive but to the pow'r,

Strongly reolve, tho' ne'er o loth to tir,

Make all the ail you can and cud away.

Salute him kindly, tho' with deep regret;
Embrace him, I'll pronounce your cure compleat.
Now to perform a true phyician's part,
And hew I'm perfect mater of my art;
I will precribe what diet you hall ue.
What food you ought to take, and what refue.
Muhrooms of ev'ry fort provoke deire,

But in a word, of all the herbs that grow,
Take only uch as keep the body low.
If my opinion you would have of wine,
It quenches love, and does to love incline.
A little breath of wind but fans the fire,
Whoe flame will in a happier blat expire.
In wine you mut no moderation keep:
You mut not drink at all; or drink o deep,
So large a doe, as put your cares to leep.
Now to our port we are arriv'd: bring down
The joly wreath, our leaky bark to crown, oo
Your grief redret, and now a happy throng,
Ye nymphs and youths applaud my healing ong.

t Al • m • on was the on of Amphiraus, and brother of Amphilochus; who endeavouring to purify himelf for the crime he had committed in murdering his mother Eriphile, came to Phegeus, father of Alpheib • a, to whom he gave his mother's fatal chain, and married her. Afterwards going to viit Achelous, he was enamoured of his daughter Callirhoe; who demanding of him that precious chain, he returned to Alpheib • a, to fetch it, but was killed by her brothers Timeno and Anonas, and buried in the Acropolis of Zacynthus, where grew cypres trees, which they call virgins. v She was the daughter of the river Troas, according to Apolladorus, and of Zanthus, according to others. When Hecuba, Priam's wife, and Paris' mother, was with child of him, he dream'd he had a firebrand in her womb, which hould conume Troy to ahes. To prevent Priam's making him away, Hecuba ent him to mount Ida, to be bred up in the mean condition of a hepherd, and when he grew up, he married Oenone. There he had a viion of the three naked goddees, and being made arbiter of their beauties, gave the golden apple upon which was written, let it be given to the fairet, to Venus, who •• d promied him the fairet woman in the world if he decided the dipute in her favour; Pallas tempted him with widom, and Juno with power, both which he <> and preferred pleaure. His father afterward <…> the knowledge of him, and admitting him to

div.p: aa Lethe, the river of forgetfulnes. There was one in Lydia of that name, another in Macedon, another in Spain, and another in Crete.

bb The poet by the wift calends undertands the month of January, when creditors ued their debtors; and this court was near the temple of Janus. They are called wit calends, for thee being days of payment, debtors thought they came round very fat. This thought reflects on the extravagance of lovers, who quander a way their etates, run in debt, and ruin themelves by their amours. The firt days; of the other months were pay-days, as well as thoe of January, but not • erms for uing; And from thee calends, Augutus ued to ay of any one that was inolvent, or would not pay his debts, he will pay at the Greek calends, that is never; the Creeks having no calends, as the Romans had.

cc. Palinurus was one of AEneas's companions, and his pilot: who falling aleep at the helm, tumbled with it in his hand into the ea, and after three days wimming, arrived at port Velino in Italy where he was robbed and killed by the inhabitants. For thus they were everely plagued, and having conulted Apollo's oracle to
appeae his ghot, conecrated a grove to him, and built him a tomb on the next promontory, called by the Italians the cape of Palinurus.

dd There's a fort of dangerous infection in it. And indeed nothing is more certain, than that what is bad is more eaily communicated to another, than what is good; which the poet jutifies by imilies, as he is wont to do.
ee The ame Mercury gave him, with which he vanquihed Maryas, who challenged him to a trial of kill in muic, for which he was a little too everely punihed.

ff Althea, wie of Oeneas, king of Calydonia, and mother of Meleagar, who hearing all her other ons were killed in a edition, in a fury lung the brand into the • ire, upon which the fate of Meleagar depended, and then •• abbed, or hanged herelf.

gg Nauplius, king of Euboea and Scriphus, the father of pulamedes, to revenge, the death of his on • et up a watch •• ght upon a promontory, which the Greeks being overtaken in a torm, took for a ignal of the afe landing place, and o fell in among the rocks, as Nauplius intended it: But he • inding Ulyes had ecaped, in a rage threw himelf into the ea.

hh 'Tis aid that Scylla, daughter of Nius, falling in love with Minos, who had beieged M • gara, of which her father was king, he cut off that lock of hair on which his trength and fortune depended, and the city being taken, he was turned into an oprey. Minos afterwards lighted Scylla; he died of depair, and was metamorphoed into a lark.
ii This • ock lies over againt Z • n • la in Sicilly, at the entrance of the treights of Meina.

kk Hecale was a poor old woman, who entertained Theeus at her cottage in one of his enterpries; and I
••• , one of Penelope's uitors, who being extremely poor, was almot tarved, and o weak that Ulyes knocked
him on the head with his fit. Irus's poverty occaioned the proverb Iro pauperior.
ll Meaning that of Mimes, where the potures were very debauched, and the fight of them dangerous to manners.
mm Soft poems, elegies of love, and pleaant ongs, revive amorous fancies, and hould be avoided.

nn In the original Lotophages, that is, eaters of the fruit of a certain tree called Lotos. The Lotophages were a people of Africa, who, as Strabo writes, inhabited an iland called Menynge: Ulyes's company having tated of this country fruit, thought no more of their return, o delicious, did they think it. The tree was as big as a pear-tree, and the fruit about the bignes of a bean of a affron colour, and extremely weet, but it changed its nature if tranplanted into Italy. The Syrens are reported to ing off this hore.

oo The poet having finihed his work, demands a time of ret, to enjoy the glory he had deerved by his labour, as the eamen when they enter their port after a long voyage: It being the cutom to adorn the hip with garlands on uch occaions.

div.p: THE COURT OF LOVE:
A VISION, AND THE HISTORY OF LOVE.
Imitated from OVID's WORKS.
TO WHICH IS ADDED, A PASTORAL ELEGY.
PART SECOND.

lg.l: ONCE as I lay by heavy leep oppres'd,
With this trange whim my fancy was poes'd,
I dreamt that Cupid call'd me to his court
On mount Cithera, where his laves reort:
Where Venus, queen and Goddes, fills the throne,
Her kingdom haring with her darling on;
There was I traight commanded to appear, <>
By Mercury, the winged meenger:
Away I went, thro' trange and ditant lands,
The coat enquiring where Love's palace tands;
At lat a crowd of travellers I found,
And ak'd them whither they o fat were bound;
One, looking like a maid, cry'd, gentle friend,
To Cupid's court our willing teps we bend;
Oh! where's his court? aid I • The nymph reply'd,
High on Cithera tands, with tow'ring pride,
A tately catle, his imperial eat,
In which he lives magnificently great.
Her teps I follow'd till my eager ight,
Reaching the hill, found her decription right
Amaz'd I aw the building large and trong,
Vat were the domes, the marble turrets long,
But gold and jewels hid the may tone,
And tretching to the kies with lutre hone;
Saphires and rubies mingled various lights
More parkling than the tars in winter nights;
And phoebus darted on this happy place
His lutre, to regain the Queen's good grace;
For chancing once unluckily to find
Mars in her arms, he had enrag'd her mind;
But now to pleae th' offended Queen he trove,
Which hew'd his longing for the weets of love.
For all the Gods that on Olympus dwell,
Ev'n Jove and pluto, kings of heav'n and hell,
All things that live on earth, or breathe above,
The mighty joys of this bet realm approve.
Arriv'd at court, I found the palace-rooms
Adorn'd with hangings made in cotly looms;
Fair maids I met, that mov'd with heav'nly grace,
And young men walking with a luty pace;
Old men I aw too, but I could not dream
What ervice Venus could receive from them.
Penive I tood, and carful to be een.
'Till one I py'd belonging to the queen,
Call'd Philomel; I knew her once a maid,
But all her life he lov'd: My friend, he aid,
Welcome to Cupia's Court; but you, I fear,
Receiv'd from Mercury a ummons here.
I anwer'd, Yes; She aid your negligence
will then be thought a wilful dire offence;
For all that live in luxury and eae,
By nature <> the charming ex to pleae,
To this fam'd palace early hould repair,
And haten to the ervice of the fair;
But you that abent durt o long remain.

l.hi: Without a boat had better cros the main,

lg.l: Than bear the cure that diobedience draws
On bold contemners of love's acred laws.
For no unhappy man uch torments bear,
As wretches doom'd to feel affliction here.
Soon they perceive their appetite decay'd.
Love makes their health decreae, their colour fade,
Long ince I tempted you to Cupia's court:
Now he'll receive you with a ullen port.
Perhaps repentance may the god auage;
But why hould you o long provoke his rage?
I anwer'd thus:—With orrow I repent,
Wretch that I am, a life o vainly pent;
And, having poke, by her I traight was led
To a vat hill, with various carpets pread,
And cloth of gold; on which I wond'ring found
A throne of tate, erected from the ground.
Where Venus at, with her imperial on;
Each had a ceptre, and a radiant crown,
To ee their pomp I could 'till now have tood,
Thoughtles of drink, and detitute of food:
The pleaures of the fam'd Elyian field,
Can no uch rapture to a tranger yield.
No wonder Venus, blet with uch a mein,
And uch a peron, reigns, of beauty queen,
Her golden hair, dihevell'd, crip and long,
In eay curls, around her houlder hung;
And every beam that's darted from her eyes,
Piercing and harp, like pointed arrows flies,
The king of Love, had danger by his ide,
The Queen depair: And looking further wide,
Attendance, fear, and flattery, I view'd,
And hope, with trength, above the ret endu'd;
And wrinkled jealouy, with young delight,
Open and free, and cheerful to the fight;
And envy lurking in a ecret place,
Lean was her body, leering was her face;
Repining at the fortunate he at,
And at that ditance one might ee her fret.
Below the throne, an humble ighing crowd
With preing uits, and warm petitions bow'd.
Then Philomel I ak'd whence came the tide
Of all thoe througing uppliants? She reply'd,
From divere realms they come: Thoe dret in blue,
Shew by that colour, they have till been true.
The men in black lament, that thoe they love
Are ick, or dead, or that they cruel prove.
What makes thoe priets, aid I, in court appear?
Have they the privilege of erving here?
The dame reply'd, full many maids can tell
None are more welcome, and none erve o well.
While thus I view'd, with Philomel, the crowd,
A herald from the king cry'd out aloud,
Come all ye trangers, to the throne, draw near,
And intantly before the king appear.
In hate I ran, and kneel'd before the throne,
All pale and trembling; as a wretch undone:
The king look'd ternly, and demanded, why
I came o late, and what I could reply?
Weeping, I anwer'd, Oh, my ov'reign lord,
One act of mercy to your lave afford;
If yet, a rebel both in word and thought,
I never lov'd o truly as I ought;
I will henceforth endeavour to fulfil
The jut decrees of your almighty will.
Well, all is pardon'd, he reply'd, If now
To me allegiance and true faith you'll bow:
Then traight <> call'd an officer of tate,
His name is Rigour, olemn was his gait,
And grim his look, unmov'd with gold or pray'r;

l.U: tatute-book, he brought, and aid, 'You wear

lg.l: True to remain, in deed, in thought, and word,
To Venus, and her <> your ov'reign lord
' To love one fall unchangeably 'till death,
' And own your paion with your latet breath,
' To bear the various temper of her mind,
' And let her will your jut obedience find:
' To give the honour to her virtue due,
' And think all tales that blat her fame, untrue:
' To wear her conduct is exactly right,
' And in defence of that opinion fight:
' To find what preent and device he loves,

' To write, to dres, to practie ev'ry art
' Yourelf to recommend, and gain her heart:
' To take no pleaure abent from her ight,
' But by reflecting on your pat delight;
' Nor abence long endure, but jutly chue,
' Rather than live from her, your life to loe.'
All this I wore; and as I turn'd the book,
On other tatutes of the realm to look,
Rigour cry'd out, hold, traitor to the queen,
Thoe acred tatutes are not to be een:
Thoe are the laws for womankind ordain'd,
That with men's eyes were never yet profan'd;
Nor e'en with mine, tho' I on Venus wait,
Long truted with her deep affairs of tate.
Believe me, friend, mankind mut till depair
To know the rules and maxims of the fair.
And when you ee them change with ev'ry wind,
Themelves indulging, to their laves unkind,
Conclude their duty to thee laws they pay;
Which, • ho' unwillingly, they mut obey.
Now eek the temple of the Queen of Love,
All you whoe choice is made, her grace implore,
To erve and pleae the ladies you adore;
And each that <…> , pray to • ind
By her propitious, <…>
We all obey'd the <> that Rigour poke,
Ent'ring the temple, which fam'd artits built,
Soft was the front, the lovely roof was gilt:
The cheerful choir with well-carv'd works was lin'd,
And am'rous paintings on the pillars hin'd.
There Dido, that unhappy dying queen,
With fale AEneas, in one piece was een.
And other pictures round the walls were pread,
Of men and maids, for love untimely dead.
Rais'd in the middle ile, fond ouls to awe,
A golden image of the queen we aw;
This all ador'd: Some looking freh and fair,
Some worn with grief, or blated by depair:
Some in new mantles dret; and ome in old,
Like half-tarv'd beggars, ugly to behold.
Some pale as death appear'd; ome glow'd like fire.

l.U: o their inward fierce deire:

lg.l: Thee with their lo • d complaints the queen beought
To cure thoe ills, that cruel love had wrought;
And punih all uch authors of their woes,
As mock'd their uff'rings, or had broke their vows.
But all the happy there, whoe envy'd lives,
Were blet with joys which bounteous Venus gives,
Cry'd, goddes, had! propitious to redres
The cares of mortals, and their hearts to bles;
May no diviions in your realm be found,
Since the whole world in love's oft chains is bound;
This is the life of joy your vot'ries know.
Who feel their blis of paradie below;
Love cures our vices, and refines our hearts;
The ource of manners, indutry, and parts:
Honour to you, celetial queen, we pay,
Whoe minds are lighted with your beauty's ray.
Taught by the pray'rs thoe happy lovers made
I try'd my wit, and thus devoutly aid;
Fairet o • a •• that e'er in nature hin'd,
Light of the <> , and <> of mankind,
To you, O goddes, I my <…>
Freely <…> death.
Yours be the choice, I only wih to find
A faithful mitres, beautiful, and kind;
No woman yet my ettled paion moves;
One I have een, whom mot my oul approves;
Of tature low, cat in a lovely mould,
Healthful and young, with hair more bright than gold;
Her looks are freh, her countenance demure,
Her eyes tho' killing, look like crytal pure:
Her could I erve; but if your high decree
That fair denies, ome other find for me,
With whom in pleaure I may pend my life;
MY mitres, empres, any thing but wife.
So will I always acrifice to you,
And with Diana contant war purue;

l.hi: A fig for her and all her chatity,

lg.l: Let monks and friars her diciples be.
Thus in the temple having aid my pray'r,
Another image I dicover'd there;
A tender maid, aid Philomel, does claim
That acred hrine, and Pity is her name:
In all the court, none knows o well the art
To help a lover, or to ave a heart:
Her all-commanding int'ret cannot fail;
Gain but her friendhip, and you mut prevail.
Now you hall ee the fairet thing alive,
Come on with me, and by your carriage trive
To pleae a Lady of the nicet tate.
Whoe air is prudent, as her life is chate:
Call'd Roalinda; could you gain her grace,
Well might you bles the goddes of this place:
Take care your ene and modety to how,
She hates a p • rt, inipid, prating beau,
Then traight he led me to a pacious room,
Where Roalinda at in beauty's bloom:
At the firt fight a hiv'ring pain I found;
In all my veins, my heart receiv'd a wound;
I dreaded much to peak, my voice was broke,
Yet when my ighs permitted, thus I poke;
Accept my ervice, thou celetial fair,
And oh! receive a dying lover's care;
To your commands my painful heart I bind,
And have for ever liberty reign'd.
She made no anwer, and I oon retir'd,
To pres not daring, tho' by love inpir'd;
But till her image dwelt within my breat,
Too excellent to be in vere expret.
Her head is round, and flaxen is her hair,
Her eye-brows darker, but her fore-head fair,
Straight is her noe; her eyes like em'ralds bright:
Her well-made cheeks are lovely red and white;
Short is her mouth, her lips are made to kis,
Roy and full, and prodigal of blis;
Her teeth like iv'ry are, well-iz'd and even:
And to her breath etherial weets are given:
Her hands are nowy white, and mall her wait,
And what is yet untold is ure the bet.
Had Jove himelf beheld this heav'nly fair,
Calito never had been made a tar;
He ne'er had borne Europa on his back,
Nor turn'd a mortal for Alcmena's ake;
Nor try'd the virtue of a golden hower,
To enter Danae's Well-defended tower:
For all their beauties had too mean appear'd.
With Roalinda's matchles charms compar'd.
Soon I return'd her heav'nly form to view,
And till my wound's impreion deeper grew;
And thus I poke: O nature's boated pride.
For torments caus'd by you ome cure provide:
Prais'd be my fate, and ever blet the hour,
That made me ubject to your lawful pow'r:
Not Antony could greater paion boat,
Tho' for one woman the whole world be lot.
The anwer'd, Friend, your service I diclaim,
Who are you, pray? Whence come you? What's your name?
Men call me Celadon, in vere I write,
And ongs at home, with ome applaue, ind •• e
Oh, why is ev'ry flow'r and pleaing root,
That in the mues happy garden hoot,
Deny'd me now? And why mut I depair,
With weets of vere, to charm the brightet fair?
Thus, gentle mue, my humble breat inpire
With acred numbers and celetial fire;
And, Pallas, thy propitious light convey,
To chace the mit of ignorance away—.
Peace, rhyming fool, and learn henceforth to make
A • itter choice; your woman you mitake.
O mercy, Venus! mercy from above!
Why hould you cure me with uch helples love?
Behold the mot abandon'd oul on earth;
I •• was I got, and woful was my birth.
Unles ome pity on my pain you hed,

l.hi: The froty grave will quickly be my bed.

lg.l: Thus having poke, my voice began to fail,

I woon'd, and down I fell. Thou lave, arie,

I only try'd thy heart; and ince I find
'Tis oft and tender, know that mine is kind.
Swear but to keep the oath you lately took,
And I'll not be o cruel as I look.
Her eyes then languih'd and her face grew red.
And queezing fat my hand, he laughing aid.
I know a way thy paion to appeae,

But •• er • he brought me to her promis'd bed,

YE woods, and wilds, erene and blet retreats,
At once the lovers, and the mues feats;
To you I fly, to you, ye acred groves,
To tell my wondrous tale of wondrous loves.
Thee, Delia, thee hall ev'ry hepherd ing,
With thy dear name the neighb'ring woods hall ring,
No name but thine hall on their banks be found,
With none but thine hall echoing hills re • ound.
My vere, thy matchles beauties hall proclaim,
'Till thine out-rivals Sacharia's fame.
My vere hall make thee live, While woods hall grow
While there remains alive a tender maid,
Or am'rous youth, or love-ick wain to read.
Others may artfully the paions move,
In me alone 'tis natural to love.
While the world ees me write <> uch a train,
As hews, I only feel, what others feign,
Thou darling of my youth, my life's delight,
By day my viion, and my dreams by night;
Thou who alone dot all my thoughts infue,
And art at once, my mitres and my mue:
Inpir'd from thee, flows every acred line,
Thine is the poetry, the poet thine.
Thy ervice hall my only buines be,
And all my life employ'd in pleaing thee,
Crown'd with my ongs of thee, each day hall move,
And ev'ry lit'ning • un hear nought but love.
With flowing numbers, ev'ry page hall roll,
Where, as you read my vere, receive my oul,
Should ene, and wit, and art, refue to join,
In all I write, and fall my great deign:
Yet with uch paion hall my lines be crown'd,
And o much oftnes in my poem found,
Such moving tendernes; the world hall ee,
Love could have been decrib'd by none but me.
Let Dryden from his works, with jutice, claim
Immortal praie; I from my acred flame
Draw all my glory, challenge all my fame.
Believe me, Delia, lovers have their wars,
And Cupid has his camp, as well as Mars,
That age which uit, a oldier bet, will prove
The fittet for the harp fatigues of love.
None but young men the toils of war can bear.
None but young men can erve and pleae the fair.
Youth, with the for maintains the vig'rous ight,
Youth, gives the longing maid the full delight,
On either hand, like hardhip it utains,
Great are the oldier's great the lover's pains.
Th' event of war no <> can foreknow,

argument.p: Leander accutomed nightly to wim over the Hellepont to viit Hero, (prietes of Venus's temple) being at lat hindered by torms from his wonted coure, ent her the following epitle.

lg.l: READ this; yet be not troubled when you read,
Your lover comes not, in his letter's tead,
On you all health, all happines attend,
Which I would much, much rather bring than end.
But now thee envious torms obtruct my way,
And only this bold bark durt put to ea.
I too had come, had not my parents' pies,
Stood by to watch me with upicious eyes,
How many tedious days and nights are pat,
Since, I was uffer'd to behold you lat!
Ye piteful gods and goddees, who keep
Your watry courts within the pacious deep,
Why at this time, are all the winds, broke forth?
Why well the eas beneath the furious north?
'Tis ummer now when all hould be erene:
Winter is yet unwilling to appear,
But you invert the eaons of the year.
Yet let me once attain the wih'd for beach,
Out of the now malicious Neptune's reach:
Then blow, ye winds; ye troubled billows roar;
Roll on, you angry waves, and lah the hore.
Ruffle the eas, drive the tempetuous air;
Be one continu'd torm, and keep me there.
Ah! Hero, when to you my coure is bent,
I eem to lide along a mooth decent.
But in returning thence, I clamber up.
And cale, methinks, ome lofty mountain's top.
Why, when our ouls by mutual love are join'd,
Why are we under'd by the ea and wind?
Either make my Abydos your retreat,
Or let your Se •• os be my much lov'd eat.
This plague of abence I can bear no more,
Come what can come, I'll hortly venture o'er.
Not all the rage of eas, nor force of torms.
Nothing but death hall keep me from thy arms:
Yet may that death at lat to friendly prove,
To float me to the coat of her I love.
Let not the thought occaion any fear:
Doubt not, I will be oon and afely there:
But 'till that time, let this employ your hours,
And hew you, that I can be none but yours.
Mean-while the veel from the la • d withdr • w,
When heav'n took pity on a <…> :
The winds to blow, the waves to <…> .
In leaps the ravih'd youth, and ventures o'er.
With a mooth paage to the farther hore.
Now to the p • rt the prop'rous lover drives.
And afely after all his toils arrives.
Diolv'd in blis, he lies the live-long night,
Melts, languihes, and dies in vat delight;
But that delight my mue forbears to ing.
She knows the weaknes of her infant wing.
AS when the painter trove to draw the chief
Of all the Grecians, in his height of grief:
In ev'ry limb the well-hap'd piece excell'd,
But coming to the face, his pencil fail'd.
There modetly he taid, and held, for fear
He hould not reach the woe he fancy'd there;
But round the mournful head a veil he threw.
That men might gues at what he could not hew.
So when our pleaure ries to exces,
No tongue can tell it, and no pen expres.
Love will not have his myteries reveal'd,
And beauty keeps the joys it gives conceal'd.
And 'till thee joys my Delia lets me know,
To me they hall continue ever o.
Ah! Delia, would indulgent love decree,
Thy faithful lave that heav'n of blis with thee;
What then hould be my vere? What darling flights
Should my mue take? reach what celetial heights?
Now in depair, with drooping notes he ings,
No dawn of hope to raie her on her wings,
In the warm pring the warbling birds rejoice,
And in the miling un-hine tune their voice.
Bak'd in the beams, they train their tender throats,
Where cheerful light inpires the charming notes.
Such, and o charming hould my numbers be,
If you, my only light, hould mile on me.
Your influence would inpire as moving airs.
And make my ong as oft and weet as theirs.
Would you but once aupiciouly incline
To raie his fame, who only writes for thine;
I'd ing uch notes, as none but you can teach,
And none but one who loves like me can reach.
Secure of you, what raptures could I boat!

l.U: hall I <> when you are lot!

lg.l: Ah! think what pangs depairing lovers prove,
And what a blet etate were mutual love.
How might my oul be with your favour rais'd!
And how in pleaing you, myelf be pleas'd!
With what delight, what tranport could I burn
Did but my flames receive the leat return.
How would one tender look, one pitying mile,
Or one kind word from you, reward my toil!
It mut, and would your tend'ret pity move,
Were you but once convinc'd how well I love,
By ev'ry pow'r that rules and reigns on high,
By love, the mighty't pow'r of all the ky;
By your dear elf, the lat great oath, I wear,
That neither life, nor oul are half o dear.
What need I thee uperfluous vows repeat?
Already igh'd o often at your feet.
You know my paion is incere and true,
I love you to exces; you know I do.
No tongue, no pen, can what I feel expres,
Ev'n poetry itelf mut make it les.
You haunt me till, wherever I remove
There's no retreat ecure from fate or love.
My oul from yours, no ditance can divide,
No rocks, no caves, can from your preence hide.
By day, your lovely form fills all my ight,
Nor do I loe you, when I loe the light,
You are the charming phantom of the night.
Still your dear image dances in my view,
And all my retles thoughts run till on you.
You only are the leeping poet's dream.
And when awake, you only are his theme.
Were I, by ome yet harder fortune, hurl'd
To the remotet part of all the world;
The coldet northern clime, the torrid zone,
should hear me ing of you, and you alone.
That pleaing tak hould all my hours employ,
<…> charming melancholy joy.
The chorus of the birds, the whip'ring boughs,
And murm'ring tream, hould join to ooth my woes
My thoughts of you hould yield a ad delight,
While joy and grief contend like day and night.
With miles, and tears, reembling un and rain,
To keep the pleaure, I'd endure the pain.
If uch content my troubled oul could know,
Such atisfaction mixt with o much woe;
If but my thoughts could keep my wihes warm,
Ah! how would your tranporting preence charm!
How pleaant would thoe pathles wilds appear,
Were you alone my kind companion here!
What hould I then have left me to deplore?
Oh! what ociety to wih for more?
No country thou art in can deert be,
And towns are deolate depriv'd of thee.
Banih'd with thee, I could an exile bear;
Banih'd from thee, the banihment lies there.
I to ome lonely ile with thee could fly,
Where not a creature dwells but thou and I;
Where a wide preading main around us roars,
Beprinkling, with its foam, our deert hores;
Where winds and waves in endles wars engage,
And high-wrought tides roll with eternal rage;
Where hips far off their fearful coures teer,
And no bold veel ever ventures near.
Should riing eas well over ev'ry coat.
Were mankind in a econd deluge lot,
Did only two of all the world urvive,
Only one man, one woman left alive;
And hould the gods that lot to us allow,
Were I Deucalion, and my Pyrrha thou;
Contentedly I hould my fate embrace,
And would not beg them to renew our race;
And my mot ardent wihes hould implore,
All I hould ak from each indulgent pow'r,
Would be to keep the • afe, and have no more.
Your cruelty occaions all my mart,
Your kindnes could retore my bleeding heart.
You work me to a torm, you make me calm;
You give the wound, and can infue the balm.
Of you I boat, of you alone complain,
My greatet pleaure and my greatet pain.
Whene'er you grieve I can no comfort know,
And when you firt are pleas'd, I mut be o.
While you are well, there's no dieae I feel,
And I enjoy no health, when you are ill.
Whate'er you do, my actions to direct,
Your mile can raie me, and your frown deject,
Whome'er you love, I, by the elf ame fate,
Love too; and hate whatever wretch you hate.
With yours, my wihes and my paions join.
Your humour, and your int'ret, all is mine.
I • are in all; nor can my fortune be
Unhappy, let but fortune mile on thee.
You can preerve, you only can detroy.
Increae my orrow, or create my joy.
From you, and you alone my doom I wait,
You are the tar, whoe influence rules my fate.
On yours my being, and my life depend,
And mine hall lat no more, when yours mut end.
No toil would be too great, no tak too hard,
Were you at lat to be my rich reward.
In erving you I'd pend my latet breath,
Brave any danger, run on any death.
I live but for your ake, and when I die,
All I hall pray for, is, may you be by.
No life, like living with thee, can delight:
No death can pleae, like dying in thy ight.
Oh! When I mut by heav'n's evere de ••• e,
Be natch'd from all that's dear, be natch'd from thee,
May't thou be preent, to dipel my fear.
And often with thy charms the pangs I bear.
While on thy lips I pour my parting breath.
Look thee all o'er and clap thee cloe in death:
Sigh out my oul upon thy panting breat,
And with a paion not to be expret
Sink at thy feet into eternal ret.
WITH uch delight I read your letter o'er
Your preence only could have giv'n me more.
Excue my paion, if it oar above
Your thought; no man can judge of woman's love.
With bus'nes you, or pleaures may utain
The pangs of abence, and divert the pain
The hills, the vales, the woods, and treams are tor'd
With game, and profit with delight afford.
Whilt gins for beats, and nares for fowls you et,
You mile, and your own am'rous chains forget.
Ten thouand helps beides effect your cure,
Whilt woman's ole relief is to endure.
Or, with one confident I hold dicoure,
Debating what hould interrupt your coure;
Or viewing from aloft the troubled tide,
Mix in the fray, and with the tempet chide,
Or in the torm's leat interval upect
Your tay, and almot charge you with neglect
I eek your footteps on the and in vain.
The ands no more confes thee than the main.
I watch th' arriving barks, and never fail.
T' enquire of you, and write by ev'ry ail.
Still as the etting un retores the night
(The night to me more welcome than the • ight)
I fix my flaming torch to guide my love,
Nor hines there any friendlier tar above.
Then with my work or book the time I cheat,
And 'midt the tak Leander's name repeat.
My wedded thoughts no other theme purue,
I talk a hundred things—but all of you.
What think't thou, nure, does my Leander come?
Or waits he till his parents leep at home?
For he is forc'd to teal his paage there,
As nightly we by tealth admit him here.
Think't thou that now he trips him in the bay,
Or is already plung'd, and on his way?
Whilt he, poor oul, with tedious watchings pent,
Makes half replies, and nodding, gives aent.
Yet cannot I the mallet paue allow,
But cry, he is launch'd forth for certain now,
Then ev'ry moment thro' the window peep;
With greedy eyes examine in all deep;
And whiper to the floods a tender pray'r
In your behalf, as if I py'd you there.
Or to beguile my griefs my • ar incline,
And take each gentle breeze's voice for thine:
At lat urpriz'd with leep, in dreams I gain
That blis, for which I wak'd o long in vain.
To hroud you then my houlders I divet,
And clap you hiv'ring to my warmer breat.
A lover need not be inform'd the ret.
Thee pleaures oft my lumb'ring thoughts employ,
But till they're dreams, and yield no olid joy.
Tho' ne'er o lively the fruition be,
To fill my blis, I mut have very thee.
At preent, I confes the eas are rough,
But were lat night compos'd and ca • m enough,
Why did you then my longing hopes delay?
Why diappoint me with a total tay?
Is it your fear that makes my wihes vain?
When rougher, you have oft engag'd the main;
If it be fear that friendly fear retain.
Nor viit me till you ecurely may:
Your danger would afflict me more than tay.
Dread ev'ry gut that blows, but oh! my mind
Migives, if you prove various as that wind.
If e'er you change, your error ecret keep,
And in blet ignorance, oh! let me leep,
Not that I am inform'd you're chang'd at all,
But abent lovers fear whate'er may fall.
Detain'd by floods, your tay I will not blame:
But les I dread the floods than ome new flame.
Be huht ye winds, ye raging billows leep,
And yield my love afe paage thro' the deep.
Blet ign, the taper parkles while I pray,
I gues i' th' flame! Leander's on his way!
Our houhold altar yields propitious igns,
From which my nure your wift approach divines.
The crickets too of your arrival warn.
And ay our number hall increae e'er morn.
Come, gentle youth, and with thy preence make
The glad conjecture true: the day will break.
And mar our blis, prevent the hat'ning morn;
To me and love's foraken joys return.
My bed without thee will afford no ret;
There is no pillow like Leander's breat.
Dot thou upect the time will be too hort?
Or want't th •• trength th' adventure to upport?
if this detain thee, oh! no longer tay.
I'll plunge and meet thee in the flood half way.

Thus in th ••
<> waves our flames hall meet,
And danger make the oft <> more weet.
Our love's our own, which yet we take by <> ,
Like midnight <> from their hidden wealth.
'Twit <> and love unhappy made,
Whilt ame forbids what our deires peruade
How art thou • ight • y natch'd from <…>
To dare th • floods when ailors keep the bay
Yet be advis'd <…> of the <>
Nor in thy youthful trength <…>
Think not thine arms can more than oars prevail;
Nor dare to wim, where pilots fear to ail.
With much regret I cautiouly peruade.
And almot wih'd my counel diobey'd.
Yet when to the rough main my eyes I turn,
Methinks I never can enough forewarn:
Nor does my lat night's viions les affright,
(Tho' expiated with many a acred rite)
A porting Dolphin whilt the flood retir'd,
Lay hid i' th' Ooze, and on the Beach expir'd.
Whate'er the dream portend, as yet reide.
In the afe port, nor trut th' incontant tide.
The torm (too fierce to lat) will oon decay,
Then with redoubled peed redeem your tay,
Till then thee heets ome pleaure may impart,
They bring what mot you prize, your Hero's heart.

div.head: The Parting of ACHILLES AND DEIDAMIA.

argument.p: Achilles had a long time lain diguied like a woman, in the court of Necomedes, king of Bithynia, making ue of that habit, the better to carry on his amours with Deidamia, Necomedes's daughter, but he was at lat dicovered by the ubtilty of Ulyes; who putting a word into his hands, which • e wielded too dexterouly for a woman, o betrayed, and w • rn • d him to the Trojan war, the Greeks having been warned by the Oracle, that Troy hould •• ver be taken, unles Achilles aited at the iege.

lg.l: THUS young Achilles, in Bithynia's court,
Had made a private, and a long reort:
Dret like a maid, the better to improve,
With his fair princes, undicover'd love.
Where hours and days, he might ecure receive
The mighty blis that mutual love could give.
Where in full joy the youthful pair remain'd
And nought a while but laughing pleaures reign'd.
'Till at the lat, the gods were envious grown,
To ee the blis of man urpas their own.
All Greece was now with Helen's, rape alarm'd,
And all its princes to revenge her arm'd.
When piteful pow'rs foretold them their deent
Would be in vain, unles Achilles went.
In vain they might the Phrygian coat invade.
Scale Troy in vain, no onet could be made,
That hould ucceed without that hero's aid.
And now Ulyes by a crafty leight.
Had found him out in his diguie's pight,
Who, tho' betray'd by his unhappy ate,
Had too much <…> honour to retreat.
Which when his charming Deidamia kn • w.
She to her late dicover'd lover flew,
On his dear neck her nowy arms he hung.
And treaming tears awhile retrain'd her tongue,
But he at lat, her dimal ilence broke,
Thee mournful words the weeping princes poke.

Whither, ah! whither would Achilles
<> ?
From all he's dearet to, from love and me?
Are not my charms the ame? the ame that pow'r?
Have I lot mine? or has Bellona more?
Oh! let me not o poorly be forook,
But view me, view me, with your uual look.
Would you unkind from thee embraces break?
•• glory grown o trong? or I o weak?
Glory is not your only call, I • ear,
You go to meet ome other mitres there.
Go then, ungrateful, tho' from me you fly,
You'll never meet with one o fend as I.
But ome camp mitres, lavih of her charms,
Devoted to a thouand rival arms,
Then will you think, when he is common grown,

<>
Deidamia, who was all our own.
Then will I clap thee to my panting breat,
And thus detain thee to my boom pr • t.
And while I old thee thus, and thus dipene
Thee kies to restore my wand'ring ene,
What dimal found of war hall natch thee hence?
What tho' the gods have order'd you hould go
Or <> return inglorious from her foe?
Have not • he felt ame cruel gods <> .
That if you w • nt, you hould as urely bleed?
Then ince your fate is detin'd to be <>
Ah! Think, can any Troy be worth o <> ?
<…> whate'er he pleae, for <…>
<> at <> hall my Achilles live
<> , built by heav'nly hands may tard, <…>
You never shall obey the <…>
Your Deidamia wears you hall not go,
Life would be dear to you, if he were o.
If not your own, at leat my afety prize,
For with Achilles, Deidamia dies.
All this, and more, the lovely mournful maid,
Told the ad youth, who igh'd at all he aid.
Yet would he not this reolution break,
Where all his fame and honour lay at take.
Now would he think on arms; but when he gave
A ide-long glance on her he was to leave,
Then his tumultuous thoughts began to jar,
And love and glory held a doubtful war.
'Till with a deep-drawn igh, and mighty coure
Of tears, which nothing ele but love could force,
To the dear maid he turns his wat'ry eyes,
And to her ad dicoure, as ad replies.
Thou late great bleing of my joyful heart,
Now grown my grief, ince I mut now depart,
Behold the pangs I bear; look up and ee
How much I grieve to go; and comfort me.
Cure on that cunning traitor's mooth deceit,
Whoe craft has made me, to my ruin great.
Cure on that artifice by which I fell,
Cure on thoe hands for wielding words o well.
Tho' I hould ne'er o fit for battle prove,
All my ambition's to be fit for love.
In his oft wars I would my life beguile,
With thee contend in the tranporting <> ,
Ravih'd to read my triumph in thy mile.
Boldly I'd trive, yet ev'n when conqu'ring yield
To thee the glory of the bloodles field.
With liquid fires, melt the rich beauties down:
Rifle thy wealth, yet give thee all my own.
So hould our wars be rapture and delight;
But now I'm ummon'd to another • ight.
'Tis not my fault, that I am forc'd away;
But when my honour calls I mut obey.
<> I not death and ev'ry danger brave,
I were not worthy of the blis I have.
More hazards than another would I <> ,
Only to lay more laurels at your feet.
Oh! do not fear that I hould faithles prove,
For you, my only life, have all my love.
The thought of you hall help me to ubdue,
I'll conquer fater to return to you.
But if my honours hould be laid in dut,
And I mut fall, as heav'n has aid I mut;
Ev'n in my death, my only hopes will be,
That I for ever hall be match'd from thee
That, that alone occaions all my fears,
Shakes my reolves, and melts me into tears.
My beating heart pan • s to thee as I peak,
And wihes rather than depart, to brea • .
Feel how it trembles with a pa ••• fright:
Sure it will never fail me thus in fight.
I cannot longer hold this fond dicoure,
For now the trumpet founds the <> divorce.
Sound ev'ry trumpet there, beat ev'ry drum;
Ue all your charms to make Achilles come.
Farewel • —Alas! I have not time to tell
How wond'rous loath I part,—once more farewel.
Remember me, as I remember you,
Gods, I hall ne'er be gone; adieu, adieu, adieu.
Happy that an • 'rous youth, whoe mitres hears
His welling ighs, and <> his falling tears,
<…> a • d her pity <> deny
<…> and a <…>
<…> them all <…>
While <…> of his <>
Yet wretched as he is, he might be blet,
would he himelf contribute to his ret:
would he reolve to truggle thro' the net.
And, but a while, endeavour to forget.
But his mad thoughts run ev'ry paage o'er.
And anxious mem'ry, makes his paion more.
Perplexing mem'ry, that renews the cene
Of all pat cares, and keeps him till in pain.
Keeps a poor wretch perpetually oppres'd,
And never lets unhappy lovers ret.
Lets them no pangs, no cruel uff'rings loe.
But heaps their pat upon their preent woes.
Such was Leander's mem'ry when remov'd,
And under'd by the eas, from all he lov'd.
The gather'd winds had wrought the tempet high,
Tos'd up the ocean, and obcur'd the ky;
And at this time, with an impetuous way,
Pour'd forth his forces, and poes'd the ea.
When the bold youth tood raging on the beach.
To view the much lov'd coat he could not reach.
His retles eyes ran all the ditance o'er.
And from afar dicern'd his Hero's tow'r.
Thrice naked, in the waves his kill he • ry'd,
And trove, as he was us'd to tem the tide.
But tumbling billows, threaten'd preent wreck,
And riing up againt him dah'd him back,
Then, like a gallant oldier, forc'd to go,
Full of brave wrath, from a prevailing foe;
Again, to town he makes his ad reort,
To ee what hips would looen from the port.
Finding but one durt launch into the eas.
He writes a letter, fill'd with words like theeSee page 152,

div.head: THE HISTORY OF PYGMALION:
Imitated from the Tenth Book of OVID's METAMORPHOSES.

lg.l: HOW art thou envy'd? let Pygmalion prove;
Who by a miracle obtain'd his love:
Who living in an age, when women led
The lewdet lives, all hame and honour fled:
For a long time declin'd the • uptial bed.
He aw them all debauch'd with montrous crimes,
No virtuous maid, no Delia bles'd the times.
Had he liv'd then, his kill had ne'er been hewn,
Nor the trange miracle that crown'd it known.
There had he fix'd, nor form'd his fancy'd maid;
Not fondly been by his own art betray'd.
The nymph in polih'd iv'ry glitter'd bright.
So mooth, he eem'd too lipp'ry for his ight.
• o curious was her hape, o jut her frame.
• o quick here eyes appear'd o full of flame,
They would have roll'd, if not retrain'd by hame.
From his trong art, the tatue had receiv'd
Such lively trokes, one would have thought it liv'd
Ev'n he himelf could hardly, hardly know,
But doubting long, whether it liv'd, or no.
Yet from her, as he was, he gather'd fires:
And fierce and boundles were his mad deires
He felt her fleh (his fancy thought it uch)
And fear'd to <…> with too rude a touch.
<> kis'd her, with belief o trong and vain.
That he imagin'd <> he kis'd again.
<> makes his <> , his mad addrees <>
<…> have <…>
Preents her now, with all he thought might pleae,
With precious gums ditill'd from weeping trees.
Small inging birds, who train their tuneful throats,
And hov'ring round, repeat their pretty notes.
With weetet flow'rs he crowns her lovely head,
And lays her on the oftet downy bed.
In richet robes his charming idol dret,
Bright parkling gems adorn her neck and breat,
And he—look'd well in all, but look'd when naked bet.
Now Venus kept her feat; a goodly train
Of love-ick youths frequent, and fill her fane.
The now-white heifers fall by acred trokes,
While with rich gums the loaded altar mokes.
Among the ret, the hopeles lover tands,
Tears in his eyes, his off rings in his hands;
More furious than before he feels his fires,
Ev'n his depair redoubles his deires.
A long, long time, his orions deferr'd,
He durt not pray, left he hould not be heard.
'Till urg'd by love, his tim'rous ilence broke,
Thus (but till tim'rouly) at lat he poke.
If you, ye acred pow'rs that rule above,
And you, great goddes of propitious love;
If all we want is plac'd within your pow'r,
And you can give whatever we unplore:
Exert you god-head now, now lend your aid,
Give me the wife! I wih, one like, • e aid,
But durt not ay, give me my iv'ry maid.
This finih'd; thrice aupicious flahes rie
And wreaths of curling moke acended <>
Half hoping now, and yet till half afraid,
With doubtful joy he eeks his iv'ry maid,
Do • ts more than ever on her fancy'd charms,
And cloely claps her in his longing arms.
When all at once, with joy and wonder fill'd,
He feels her tubborn ides begin to yield.
Soft was her boom grown, her throbbing breat,
Heav'd with her breath, well'd gently to be pret.
Surpriz'd, and glad, he feels her oft, and oft:
And more, and more, perceives her warm and oft.
Warm were her lips, and ev'ry pointed kis.
With melted touches, met and moiten'd his.
Her blood now circled and her pules beat,
And life at lat enjoy'd a ettled eat.
Slowly he lifts her new and fearful ight,
And ees at once, her lover and the light.
An unborn maid, both life and lover found;
And he too, had his dep'rate wihes crown'd.
Dep'rate indeed; what propect could he ee,
Or how at firt, hope any more than me?

div.head: SAPHO TO PHAON:
div.byline: BY THE HONOURABLE SIR CARR SCROPE, BART.
div.head: The Poetes Sapho, foraken by her Lover Phaon (who was gene from Lebos to Sicily) in <> writes this Letter to him.

lg.l: WHILE Ph ••• to the <…> flies,
Conum'd, with no <…> poor Sapho di •• .
I burn, I burn, like kindled holds of corn,
When by the driving wind • the flames are borne.
My mue and lute can now no longer pleae.
They are th' employments of a mind at • ae.
Wand'ring from thought to thought I it alone
All day, and my once dear companions hun.
In vain the L • hian maid claim each a part,
Where thou alone has ta'en up all the heart.
Ah lovely youth! how cant thou cruel prove,
When blooming years and beauty bid thee love?
If none but equal charms thy heart can bind,
Then to thyelf alone thou mut be kind.
Yet worthles as I am, there was a time
When Phaon thought me worthy his eteem.
A thouand tender things to mind I call,
For they who truly love, remember all.
Delighted with the muic of my tongue,
Upon my words with ilent joy he hung,
And natching kies, topp'd me as I ung.
Kies, whoe melting touch, his oul did move.
The earnet and the coming joys of love.
Then tender words, hort ighs, and thouand charms
Of wanton arts endear'd me to his arms;
'Till both expiring with tumultuous joys,
A gentle faintnes did our limbs urprie.
Beware, Sicilian ladies! ah beware
How you receive my faithles wanderer.
You too will be abus'd, if you believe
The flatt'ring words that he o well can give.
Looe to the winds, I let my flowing hair,
No more with fragrant cents perfume the air,
But all my dres dicovers wild depair.
To whom, alas! hould now my art be hown,
The only man I car'd to pleae is gone.
Oh let me once more ee thoe eyes of thine,
Thy love I ak not, do but uffer mine.
Thou might't at leat have ta'en thy lat farewel.
And eign'd a orrow which thou didt not feel.
No kind rememb'ring pledge was ak'd by thee.
And nothing let but injuries with me.
Witnes ye gods, with what a death-like cold
My heart was eiz'd, when firt thy flight was told
Speechles and tupid for a while I lay,
And neither words nor tears could find their way.
But when my welling paion forc'd a vent,
With hair dihevell'd, cloaths in pieces rent;
Like ome ad mother thro' the treets I run,
Who to his grave attends her only on.
Expos'd to all the world myelf I ee,
Forgetting virtue, ame, and all but thee:
So ill, alas! do love and hame agree!
Tis thou alone that art my contant care,
<> pleaing dreams thou comfort't my depair;
And mak't the might that does thy form convey,
Welcome to me above the fairet day.
Then 'pight of abence, I thy love enjoy:
In cloe embraces lock'd, methinks we lie.
Thy tender words I hear, thy kies feel,
With all the joys that hame forbids to tell.
But when I waking mis thee from my bed,
And all my pleaing images are fled;
The dear deluding viion to retain,
Hay me down, and try to leep again.
• oon as I rie, I haunt the caves and groves,
Thoe concious cenes of our once happy loves)
There like ome frantic Bacchanal I walk,
And to myelf with ad ditraction talk,
Then big with grief I throw me on the ground,
And view the melancholy grotto round;
Whoe hanging roofs of mos and craggy tone
••• ights my eyes above the brightet throne
But when I py the banks, whoe gray bed
Retains the print our weary bodies made;
On thy foraken ide I lay me down,
And with a how'r of tears the place I drown.
The trees are wither'd all ince thou art gone,
As if for thee they put thy mourning on.
No warbling Bird does now with muic fill
The woods, except the mournful Philomel.
With hers my dimal notes all night agree,

Of Tercu •
he complains, and I of thee.
Ungentle youth: did't thou but ee me mourn.
<…> art, thou would't, thou would't return
Let him alone, his victory purue;
For dreadful war has nothing here to do.
This hort account will love-ick wains uffice;
He flew his foe, and traight receiv'd his prize.
Thrice happy youth, too fortunately blet;
Who only came, and conquer'd, and poet.
None of the pangs of love your blis annoy'd;
But you beheld, admir'd, and o enjoy'd.

div.head: The STORY of HIPPOMANES AND ATALANTA:
div.byline: In Imitation of Part of that in the Tenth Book of OVID's Metamorphoes.

lg.l: HIPPOMANES alone with hope inpir'd,
Might well rejoice to find his wihes fir'd,
Since well aur'd of all his wih deir'd.
His paion was all life, all oul, and flame,
He dauntles to the fatal barriers came,
With joy his vanquih'd rivals he beheld,
Aur'd to win, where all beides had fail'd.
He aw the lovely nymph out-fly the wind,
And leave her breathles uitors far behind;
Sew Atalanta wift as lightning pas,
Yet oft as Zephyrs, weep along the gras.
He knew the law, whoe cruelty decreed,

Yet if, like them, he could not run o fat,

lg.l: Her ev'ry charm his praie and wonder mov'd,
And till the more he prais'd, the more he lov'd.
Now, •• ll at once, he feels the raging fires,

I am thy champion, and epoue thy caue;

The bahful virgin no return affords,

But that the • etters, which they were deny'd.
What could he do? all that he could, he did:

Far as he could aide, and trembling poke:
My mother, concious of her beauty, trove

Who by a cruel and unjut decree,

Here I am doom'd a dreadful monter's prey,

Hate; generous youth, our common foe ubdue;

Thus poke the maid, half dying with her fears.

This hort account will love-ick wains uffice;

Thrice happy youth, too fortunately blet;
Who only came, and conquer'd, and poet.
None of the pangs of love your blis annoy'd;
But you beheld, admir'd, and o enjoy'd.

div.head: The STORY of HIPPOMANES AND ATALANTA:
div.byline: In Imitation of Part of that in the Tenth Book of OVID's Metamorphoes.

lg.l: HIPPOMANES alone with hope inpir'd,

Aur'd to win, where all beides had fail'd
He aw the lovely nymph out-fly the wind,

l.U: wift as lightning pas,

He knew the law, whoe cruelty decreed.

Yet if, like them, he could not run o fat,

Her ev'ry charm his praie and wonder mov'd,

Now had he view'd the lat unhappy trife,

<> murmurs to herelf: Ye pow'rs divine,

• y lovely tranger, ere 'tis yet too late.
<> from thy too, ah! too too certain fate,

<> a command; could thou but tay, and live.
Thou with ome fairer maid wilt happier be:
The fairet maid might be in love with thee.
So many uitors have already bled,

It is but pity ure; it is not love.
I wih, bold youth, thou would't the race decline,

Were it but left to my own partial choice,

'Twas here he paus'd, when urg'd with long delay,
The trumpet • ounds to haten them away.
Straight at the ummons is the race begun,
And ide by ide, for ome hort time they run.
While the pectators from the barriers cry.
Fly prop'rous youth, with all thy vigour fly;
Make hate, make hate, thy utmot peed inforce.
Love gives the wings to win the noble coure:
See how unwillingly the virgin flies,
Purue, and ave thy life, • nd eize the prize.
'Tis doubtful yet, whether the gen'ral voice.
Made the glad youth, or virgin mot rejoice.
Oft, in the wiftet fury of the race
And halt, and gaze, and almot faten on his fa •• .
Then fleet away again as wift as wind,

By this, he aw his trength would ne'er prevail.
But till he had a charm that could not fail.
From his looe robe a golden apple drawn,

He takes the wih'd occaion, paes by,

Again the nymph diverts her near puruit.

Again the foremot in the flow'ry plain.

Tho' ure to loe, if he the race declin'd,

Pleas'd that he lot, to the glad victor's arms
She gives the prize, and yields her dear-bought charms;

Poes'd of that, he could not but ubdue,

Yet oh! thou bet belov'd, thou loveliet maid,
Be not by too much avarice betray'd.
Prize thyelf high, no eay purchae prove,
Nor let a fool with fortune buy thy love.
Like Atalanta's conqu'ror let him be,
Brave, gen'rous, young, from every • ailing free,
And to compleat him, let him love like me.
What pains againt thy wretched life I take?
Ev'n I myelf my jealouies awake.
Such men there are, blet with uch gifts divine,

How wretched then, alas! hould Daphnis grow?
Gods! know the very thought ditracts him now?
Ev'n now perhaps ome youth with happier charms,

Ev'n now, the favours you deny'd me, eem

Cloe by your ide, all languihing he tands.
