Then glows his ravih'd oul with pointed flames,
And thoughts of heav'nly joys fill all his dreams.
Let not your paion be to me reveal'd,
But if you love, keep him your love conceal'd.

div.head: The STORY of CEPHALUS AND PROCRIS:
div.byline: Imitated from the Tenth Book of OVID's METAMORPHOSES.

lg.l: FROM Cephalus's tragic tory, • ead
What fatal michiefs jealouy may breed.
Hear that unhappy wretched huntman tell,
How by his hands, his much-lov'd Procris fell.
Hear him, lamenting his michance, complain
In the oft Ovid's adly charming train.
Happy a while, thrice happy was my life,
Blet in a beautiful and virtuous wife.
Love join'd us firt, and love made life o weet,
We prais'd the gods, that 'twas our lot to meet
Our breats glow'd gently with a mutual flame,
The ame were our deires, our fears the ame.
Whate'er one did, the other would approve,
For one our liking was, as one our love.
Then happy days were crown'd with happier nights,
And ome few months roll'd on in full delights.
Joys crowded to appear, and pleaures ran
A while in circles, e'er our woes began.
'Till I one fatal morn the chace puru'd
Of a wild boar, thro' an adjacent wood:
Where, as I hunted eager on my prey,

l.U: top'd me in my haty way.

lg.l: You may believe I do not dare to feign,
(For mis'ry never made a man o vain)
She, tho' a goddes, traight began to move
A fruitles uit, and vainly talk'd of love.
Tho' he look'd bright as when he hines on high,
In all the glories of a morning ky;
Tho' earlier than the • un's, her beams diplay,
And hew the firt approaches of the day:
I told her Procris all my oul poet,
That he alone reign'd ov'reign of my breat,
Which never would admit another guet.
Enjoy thy Procris then, the goddes cry'd;
Whom thou halt one day wih thou'dt ne'er enjoy'd.
Stung with her words, with doubts and fears oppret,
A udden jealouy detroys my ret,
Mads all my brain, and poions all my breat.
I thought the ex all fale, ev'n Procris too.
Again I thought, he could not but be true.
Her youth and beauty kindled anxious ca • .
But her known chatity condemn'd my <>
But th • n my abence does again revive,
And keep the tor • ring fancy till alive.
I thought her faith too firmly fix'd to fall.
Yet a true lover is afraid of all.
I knew not what to think, but traight I go,
Reolv'd to cure, or to compleat my woe.
A • habit diff'rent from my own I took.
Which with <> aid Aurora chang'd my look
To Athens traight, unknown to all, I came,
Ev'n to myelf I carce could eem the ame.
Hardly I got admiion to my houe,
But far, far harder to my weeping poue.
The houe itelf from ought of blame was free.
And ev'ry place expret its grief for me.
A dimal ilence reign'd thro' ev'ry room.
To mourn my los, already afe at home.
Ev'n that ad pomp of woe, ome charms could beat,
But when my Procris came, he charm'd me mot.
Black were her robes, her olemn pace was • low,
Her dres was careles, yet becoming too.
A virtuous grief dwelt deeply in her face.
But matchles beauty gave that grief a grace.
Whole how'rs of tears her treaming eyes let fall,
Yet omething wond'rous lovely hone thro' all.
Scarce could I at the charming ight forbear
From running to embrace my mournful fair,
Scarce hold from telling whom he law (tho' alter'd there)
But yet at length, my firt deign puru'd,
With words I flatter'd, and with gifts I woo'd?
All the mot moving arguments I us'd,
Oft pray'd, and pret, but was as oft refus'd.
She aid another had before ingros'd
All her affections, and my uit was lot.
would any but a mad-man further try?
But ah! that mad, that dep'rate fool was I.
I grew the more indutrious to detroy
Her matchles truth, and ruin all my joy.
Redoubled preents, and redoubled vows.
I made, and offer'd to betray my poue.
At lat, her tagg'ring faith be •• to yield,
And I'd jut won the long <> .
Thy falehood traight I cry'd too • ate <> ;
Fale to thy Cephalus for I am <> .
Since you are perjur'd, ince my Procris gr • w
Forworn and <> what <>
She, at thee words, almot of ene bereav'd,
With ad confuion found herelf deceiv'd.
Fix'd on the ground, he kept her downcat eye,
And ilence with her hame made no reply.
But to the mountains like a huntres hies,
And for my ake from all mankind he flies,
Which when I found, abandon'd and alone,
My dearer half thro' my own folly gone;
Love fiercer than before began to burn,
'Till I was raging for my wife's return.
My pray'rs dipatch'd with eagernes and hate
That he would pardon all offences pat;
Found her as kind as he was truly chate.
She came and crown'd my joys a econd time;
Forgot my jealouy, forgave my crime.
'Twas then I thought my greatet mis'ries o'er,
But fate it eems had wore, far wore in tore.
Soon as each early un began to rie,
To glad th' enlighten'd earth, and gild the kies,
I with his firt appearance rie, and trace
The woods, and hills, that yielded game to chae.
Alone I hunt, a long and tedious way,
And eldom fail to kill ufficient prey.
Then pent with toil, to cooler hades retreat,
And eek a refuge from the corching heat.
Where pleaant valleys breathe a freer air,
For my refrehment I addres this pray'r,
Come, air, I cry, joy of o'er-labour'd wains.
Come, and diffue thyelf thro' all my veins;
Breathe on my burning lips, and fev'rih breat.
And reign at large an ever-grateful guet.
Glide to my oul, and ev'ry vital part,
Ditil thyelf upon my panting heart.
By chance I other blandihments betow,
Or detiny decreed it hould be o;
As, O thou greatet pleaure of the plains,
Thou, who dot nature's richet weets excite,
And mak't me in the deert woods delight:
Breathles, and dead without thee hould I be,
For all the life I have, I draw from thee.
While thus I ung, ome one who chanc'd to hear.
Thought her a nymph, to whom I made my pray'r,
And told my Procris of her rival air.
She, kind, good oul, half dying at the news,
Would now condemn me, now again excue.
Now hopes 'tis all a falehood, now he fears;
Supects my faith as I upected hers.
Reolv'd, at lat to trut no buy tongue,
But be herelf the witnes of her wrong;
When the next day with fatal hate came on,
And I was to my lov'd diverion gone,
She roe and ought the olitary hade,
Where, after hunting, I was daily laid.
Cloe in a thicket undicern'd he tood,
When I took helter in the hady wood.
Then tretching on the gras my fainting weight,
Come much-lov'd air, I cry'd oh! come abate
With thy weet breath, this mot immod'rate heat.
On this a udden noie invades my ear,
And rutling boughs hew'd omething living there.
I rahly thinking it ome avage beat,
Threw my unerring dart with heedles hate,
Which pierc'd, O gods! my Procris thro' the breat.
She at the wound, with fearful hrieking fell,
And I alas! knew the dear voice too well.
Thither ditracted with my grief I flew,
To give my dying love a ad adieu.
All bloody was her lately nowy breat,
Her oul was hat'ning to eternal ret.
With rage I tore my robe, which cloe I bound,
To top the blood, about the gaping wound.
What pardons did I beg? what cures frame,
For my damn'd fate that was alone to blame?
When weakly raiing up her dying head,
With a faint voice, thee few ad words he aid,
" Draw nearer yet, dear author of my death,
" Hear my lat ighs, and natch my parting breath.
" But ere I die, by all that's acred wear.
" That you will never let my rival air,
" Profane my • ed, or find reception there.
" This I conjure you by your nuptial vow;
" The faith you gave me then, renew me now
" By all your love, if any love remain,
" And by that love which dying I retain.
" Aure me but of this before I go.
" And I hall bles thee for the fatal blow."
To her ad peech abruptly I reply'd,
In hate to hew her error ere he dy'd.
Quickly I ran the tragic tory o'er.
Which made her pleas'd, amidt the pangs he bore.
That done, he rolls, in death her dizzy eyes,
And with a igh, which I receiv'd, he dies.
Here did the youth his doleful tale conclude,
A tale too doleful to be long puru'd.
But this ill-choen intance will not do,
Unles my Delia could be jealous too.
But he, whene'er I woo ome other fair,
Shews no reentment, and betrays no care.
She ees me court another, as unmov'd,
As he has always een herelf belov'd,
That dreadful thought redoubles all my fear,
That drowns my hopes, and drives me to depair,
No foreign intance need of this he h • wn,
To draw it bet, I mut decribe my own.
Tho' of this kind all ages can produce
Examples proper for the mourning mue;
Yet all to m • mut the firt place reign,
None • ver was o jut, o deep as mine.
All day and night I ing, and all day long,
I love, and I depair, makes all my ong.
Revolving days the ame ad muic hear,
Unchang'd thee notes, love, and I depair.
To me, as to the echo, fate affords,
No pow'r of peech but for thoe doleful words.
Some glimpe of un, ome cheerful beams appear,
Ev'n thro' the gloomiet eaon of the year.
My clouded life admits • o dawn of light,
No ray can pierce thro' my eternal night.
All there is dimal as the hades beneath,
And all is dark as hell, as ad as death.
My anxious hours roll heavily away,
Depriv'd of leep by night, and peace by day.
My oul no repite form her uff'rings knows,
And ees no end of her eternal woes.
In a long line they run for ever on,
And till increae, and lengthen as they run.
By flight to loe my ills in vain I try,
From my depairing elf <> cannot fly.
Where e'er I go, I bear about my flame,
In cities, countries, eas, 'tis all the ame.
Scorch'd with my burning pains, I hun my houe,
And trive in open air to eek repoe.
My flames, like torches, hook in open air,
Grow with dilated heat, more furious there.
Now to the more retir'd, remotet place,
Ev'n to obcurity I fly for eae.
Retirement till oments the raging fire,
And trees, and fields, and floods, and vere conpire
To pread the flame and heighten the deire.
Wildly I range the woods, and trace the groves,
To every oak I tell my hopeles loves.
Torn by my paion, to the earth I fall,
I kneel to all the gods, I pray to all.
Nothing but echo anwers to my pray'r.
And he peaks nothing, but depair, depair.
From woods and wilds I no relief receive,
But wander on to try what eas can give.
Deep thro' the tide, not knowing where, I walk;
To the deaf winds, not knowing what, I talk.
Mad as the foaming main, aloud I rave,
While every tear keeps time with ev'ry wave.

div.head: The PASSION of SCYLLA FOR MINOS.
div.byline: FROM THE Eighth Book of OVID's Metamorphoes

lg.l: A TOW'R with ounding walls erected tands,
The acred fabric of Apollo's hands.
His harp laid by, the trings their airs dipene,
And vocal tones receiv'd their virtue thence.
This Scylla, in the time of peace, acends,
And thence her look o'er all the lawn extends:
Now with delight he views the pacious town,
Now, pleas'd with dropping little pebbles down,
Strikes a weet muic from the warbling tone.
In times of wars the elf-ame propect yields,
The pleaing horror of the bloody fields;
Long had they now in equal balance hung,
And doubtful victory depended long.
This gave her leiure to dicern and know
The ev'ral leaders of the neighb'ring foe.
Minos, their gen'ral, mot of all he knew,
More than a virtuous virgin ought to do,
Whether his helmet glitter'd form afar,
And with its waving feathers threat'ned war;
Whether his hands, the hining word would wield,
Or hi trong arm raie his refulgent hield;
Whate'er he aw him do, he prais'd and lov'd,
And kept him till in view, where e'er he mov'd.
When e'er he hook a pear, or cat a dart,
She knew not which excell'd, his trength or art.
When e'er he drew a haft, he'd wear, that o
Ev'n Phoebus would himelf dicharge his bow.
But when his naked viage he diclos'd.
His charming face to public view expos'd;
When on his foaming hore he rode the plains,
Ruling with kilful hands, the tubborn reins;
Then like tempetuous eas her paions roll,
Mad her ick brain, and rack her troubled oul.
Happy, he calls the courer which he pres'd;
Happy, the lance he couch'd within his vet
Happy, the vamplate that ecur'd his breat.
Now would he think of flying to the foe,
And would have gone, had he a way to go.
Now, headlong form the tow'r herelf have ent,
And ventur'd life, to reach her lover's tent.
Open the brazen gates, when love inpir'd,
Or act what e'er the foe he lov'd deir'd,
Silent he at with a ditracted look,
Till paion gave her leave, and then he poke.
In this unhappy war, and fatal trife,
I know not which to yield to, joy or grief.
Tho' 'tis my fate to love my country's foe,
I had not een him, had he not been o.
Yet might they let their fierce contention fall,
And making peace, make me the pledge for all.
Minos and I once join'd, our wars might ceae,
And that alliance fix a lating peace.
Well might our mother's charms a god ubdue,
If ever he could charm dear nymph like you.
Happy! thrice happy had I wings to fly
To yonder tents, where the lov'd foe does lie.
I'd tell the dear diturber of my ret,
All that I feel, could it be all expres'd,
And pour my oul into the charmer's breat.
Give all I can to make him once my own,
All he would ak, all,—but my father's crown.
This love hall ceae, thee fierce deires hall die,
E'er I by treachery my wih enjoy.
Yet when a <> foe diputes the field,
It is not afet to reit, but yield.
The tragic det • oy of his darling on,
Has brought at lat thee fatal michiefs on.
In a jut caue his vengeful word he draws,
Strong is his army to maintain his caue.
Needs mut my charming hero prop'rous prove,
Then let him owe <> conquets to my love.
Thus thouands mut be av'd who ele mut bleed,
And daily perih, if the wars proceed.
Minos, wilt thou be afe, and I be blet;
Ele he may chance to perih with the ret.
Some rah u •• owing hand his pear may dart
Againt my too, too vent'rous hero's heart.
For who, without concern, his wounds could ee?
Or who would wound him, if he knew 'twas he?
'Tis then reolv'd; let uch a chance hould fall
On him, I love o well, I'll ha •• ard all.
My country, and myelf, one gi •• I'll join,
And make the merit of his conquet mine.
To will is nothing, when we can't fulfil,
For wretch •• want of pow'r, the things we will.
The gates are kept with a ufficient guard,
And ev'ry night my father ees them barr'd.
'Tis he detroys my blis; 'tis him I fear;
Would he were with the dead, or I were there.
Might I (not inj'ring him) my blis purue?
Indulgent gods! but why invok'd I you?
We our own gods, have pow'r ourelves to bles,
And form ourelves, derive our own ucces.
The only way to proper is to dare.
For fortune litens not to lazy pray'r.
Others enflam'd with uch a fierce deire,
Have forc'd thro' all, to quench their raging fire.
Shall any other then more res'lute prove?
Thro' fire and word I'll force my way to love.
Yet to ait me here, I need not call
For fire, or word: my father's heir is all.
That, that mut crown my joys and make me blet,
Beyond whatever ele can be poet,
Beyond what can be by my words expret.

div.head: A PASTORAL ELEGY ON THE DEATH OF DELIA.

l.hi: Quan referent Muoe, vivet, dum robora tellu • ,
Dum coelum tellas, dum vebit amnis aquas.

lg.l: STAY, wretched wain, lie here, and here lament;
Pres not too far our trength, already pent.
Long has ditracting orrow made me rove
Thro' ev'ry deert plain and dimal grove,
Still ilent with exces of grief, and love.
Feebly your trembling legs beneath you go,
And bend, o'er-burden'd with the load of woe,
Stay, and this melancholy grotto chue,
A proper manion for a mourning mue.
Lay your tir'd limbs extended on the mos,
And tell the lit'ning words of Delia's los;
Here, the ad mue need no diturbance fea • ,
For not a living thing inhabits here.
Muic may give your orrows ome relief,
And I, by lit'ning to you, hare your grief.
What muic now ca • my ad numbers boat?
What mue invoke? alas! my mue is lot
Long ince my ueles pipe was thrown aide,
My reeds were broke that hour that Delia dy'd.
From her alone their inpiration came,
She gave the vere, and was the vere's theme.
For ever hould my orrows keep me dumb,
Silent as death, and huh'd as Delia's tomb;
Did not the force of love unlock my tongue,
Left her dear beauties did remain unung.
Her charms let ev'ry mue conpire to tell,
And that once done, let ev'ry mue farewel.
" This the lat tribute of my vere I bring,
" To ing her death, and then more to ing."
Be till, ye winds, or in oft whipers blow,
Ye purling treams, with gentle murmurs flow;
Let lambs forbear to bleat, and herds to low,
Let all in eay mournful numbers move,
Let all be oft and artles as my love.
Oh! he was ev'ry way divinely fair.
Charming in peron, and in oul incere.
She was, alas! more than the mue can tell,
Well worthy love, and was belov'd as well.
She was, alas! thee tears that aying draws,
Oh! 'tis a cruel, killing word: he was.
Now he no more mut tread the flow'ry plains.
No more be gaz'd at by admiring wains;
No more, the choicet flow'rs and daiies chue,
Or pluck, the pature for her tender e •• es.
Say, ye poor flocks, how often have ye tood:
And form her lovely hands receiv'd your food;
Now ye no more from thoe fair hands mut feat,
Thoe hands, which gave the flow'rs a weeter tate.
Mourn her, by whom ye were o often fed.
And cry with me, the hepherdes is dead,
" This the lat tribute of my vere I bring,
" To ing her death, and then no more to ing."
Weep for her los, relenting heav'n, and keep
Time with our tears; heav'n eems apace to weep,
In murm'ring drops the mournful rain ditills,
And able clouds warp round the ides of hills.
The goat forbears to browze, the tender ewe
Will drink no longer of the falling dew:
No morning larks their mounting wings diplay,
Or cheer with warbling airs the duky day,
On dropping boughs ad nightingales complain,
Join in my ongs, but ing like me, in vain.
In doleful notes the murm'ring turtles • oo.
Each of them eems t' have lot a Delia too.
The melting air in mits its orrow hews,
And cold damp weat the face of earth bedews,
With tears the river-gods enlarge their pring.
Swans in ad trains on welling waters ing.
In ighs the god of winds his paion vents,
And all, all nature, for her los laments.
" This the lat tribute of my vere I bring,
" To ing her death, and then no more to ing."
How often on the banks of ilver Thames,
My eyes on hers, and hers upon the treams,
Has he tood lit'ning, when I told my flames?
How often has a udden, idelong look,
Seem'd to confes her pity when I poke?
Pity he had, tho' I could never move,
In her cold breat, the leat return of love.
Pity from her, more welcome did receive,
Than all the love another fair could give.
And it was ome, ome mall relief, to ee,
She lov'd not others, tho' he lov'd not me
Say, gentle Thames, how often have I tood
Viewing her dear reflection in your flood?
When on her face I durt not gaze for fear,
How often have I look'd, and found in there?
How often have I wih'd my vere might prove
Smooth as your tream, whene'er I write of love?
Say, how your courteous waves would never flow
O'er any path where the was us'd to go,
Now let your river, like my eyes, run o'er,
Inult with fuller tides the deert hore.
And drown thoe banks, where Delia walks no more.
" This the lat tribute of my vere I bring,
" To ing her death, and then no more to ing,"
But violets, and bluhing roes fade,
Fold your ilk leaves, and hang your drooping head.
Shut up your weets, and eem, like Delia dead,
Let pring run backwards, and the vintage blat,
Let contant how'rs lay all the country wate,
Let flames unto the centre downwards tend,
And let the floods, untos'd by wings, acend.
Let all things change, and wear another face,
Let nature not appear the ame he was.
Let fowl to dwell beneath the water try,
And let the water h • rd attempt to fly:
Let wolves protect the flocks upon the plains,
Let bahful virgins woo didainful wains;
Let avage death its cruelty purue;
And, ince my Delia's dead, let me die too.
" This the lat tribute of my vere I bring,
" I ing her death, and then no more I ing."
See where the god of love all ad appears,
His moking torch extinguih'd with his tears;
Well may he weep for his declining pow'r,
His charms are done ince Delia is no more.
Thro' her he conquer'd, and thro' her he reign'd,
Her beauties his decaying way utain'd,
And he now gone, his empire is didain'd,

See where
<> , with a tately train
Of goodly nymphs decends upon the plain:
Each of them weeps, and leans upon her bow,
And mourns her fellow Delia wanting now.
The goddes grieves to ee her train decreas'd,
And welling ighs hakes ev'ry virgin breat,
Unhurt, they let the tags beide them pas,
Nor follow boars that tempt them to the chae.
In ev'ral forms of woe their grief they vent,
And all with me for Delia's los lament,
" This the lat tribute of my vere I bring,
" To ing her death, and then no more to ing."
Look yonder where the lovely nymph is laid,
I'll go, and on her earth recline my head,
Choak with my ighs, and haten to the dead.
Come hither all ye wains, with garlands come,
Pour out your richet perfumes on her tomb.
Let myrtles on her grave unplanted grow,
In ready wreaths for ev'ry lovers's brow.
Let flow'rs, unknown before, be daily een
To raie their heads above the pacious green.
Millions of blooming weets her earth urround.
And balmy gums ditil upon the ground.
Here let the tuneful mue for ever ceae,
To give unutterable orrow place.
Let ighs and treaming tears reume their coure,
And my ad eyes be their eternal ource.
I'll go and chue ome melancholy cave,
As unditurb'd and ecret as the grave.
I'll feat my eyes with nothing fair on earth,
Nor hall my ears hear any ound of mirth.
Farewel, ye charming choriters that dwell
In acred groves; ye warbling birds farewel.
Adieu ye nymphs, adieu ye fellow wains,
Ye ilver treams, weet wans, and flow'ry plain • :
Farewel all happy days and miling hours,
Refrehing vallies and delightful bow'rs.
Adieu to every grotto, ev'ry grove,
Adieu to poetry, adieu to love.

div.p: THE OECONOMY OF LOVE:
A POETICAL ESSAY.
BY DR. ARMSTRONG.

p.hi: THIS little juvenile Performance, was chiefly intended as a Parody upon ome of the Didactic Poets; and that it might be till the more ludicrous, the Author in ome places affected the tately language of Milton.

div.head: THE OECONOMY OF LOVE.

lg.l: THY bounties, LOVE, in thy oft raptures when
Timeliet the melting pairs indulge, and how,
Bet to improve the g • mal joy, how hun
The nakes that under flow'ry pleaure lurk,
I ing: if thou, fair Cytherea, deign
Gracious to mile on my attempt Tho' thou
None of the mues nine, yet oft on thee
The mues wait, oft gambol in thy train,
Tho' virgins. Come, nor leave the Boy behind,
Blind but unerring archer, Hymen, raie
Aloft thy acred torch. Your gifts I ing.
Ye youths and virgins, when your gen'rous blood
Has drunk the warmth of fifteen ummers, now
The loves invite; now to new rapture wakes,
The finih'd ene: while tung with been deire,
The madd'ning boy his bahful fetters burts;
And, urg'd with ecret flames, the riper maid,
Concious and hy, betrays her marting breat.
Yet nature not in all her ons maintains
An equal progres. This with kindly warmth
concocts to manly vigour traight; while that
Pines, crude and chill, and carce at lat attains
Imperfect life. Some light their varnih'd teed.
And (wondrous intinct!) bent on manlier port.
Cope with the maids. Alcides thus, they ay,
Roe brawny from his cradle, while the nakes,
Hung hiing round him, horrible and fell,
Sent by enrag'd Saturnia to detroy
Her rival's hope: the mighty infant grap'd
His peckled foes, and miling dah'd them down
To hell, their native clime; the pumy gore
Blotted the frighted pavement. Early thus
Was future chivalry preag'd.—Meantime
Others low ripen: men there are who carce
Feel the oft thrillings of untaught deire,
While pallid maids carce ruminate on man.
Till twenty; well if then. It boots thee much
To tudy the complexion, much the clime,
And habitudes of life. Meanwhile with me

<> encounter; now they fight ecure

But if to progeny thy views extend

Wouldt thou behold a thriving race urround

But, O my on, whether the gen'rous care

Of riing manhood. Banih from thy hades
Th' ungen'rous, elfih, olitary joy.
Hold, Saticide, thy hand! for thee alone
Did nature form thee? for thy narrow elf
Grant thee the means of pleaure? dream't thou o?
That very elf mitakes thy wier aim;
Its finer ene ungratify'd, unpleas'd,
But when from active oul to oul rebounds
The welling mingling tumult of delight.
Hold yet again, ere idle callus wrap
In ullen indolence th' atonih'd nerves;
When thou mayt fret and teae thy ene in vain,
And cure too late th' unwiely wanton hours.
Impious, forbear! thus the firt gen'ral hail

To hed thy blooms thro' the deert air,

Unhallow'd patime!—tho' the factious chief

Remote, and light of heav'n (as ert retir'd

Sore ills dimay. Pure, or the golden pride
That decks thy finger, gorgeous with the poils

Or watch, time meas'ring, oft ubtracted ly

Him, hung'ring after gold, nor words can charm,
Nor more peruaive wine: thy gold mut pay

Or braver teel mut prove thy manly arm,

The mis'ry: wore perhaps enues; a train

Such as of old ditres'd the man ele quar'd
To God's own hear, but that his wiles debauch'd

Nor did he form the holy marriage-bed
Refrain his looe embraces, when the wife
Of wrong'd Urias he educ'd; nor topt
Till murder crown'd his lut, Hence him the wrath
Of righteous Heav'n awaking, long purued
With ore dieae, and fill • d his loins with pain,

Breathe muical in acred ong. What woes!
What pains he tried! but now this plague attacks
With double rancour. and everely marks
Modern offenders: ••• ly undermines
The fame and noe, that by uneemly lape

Nice Ta • iacotius' art, with ubtitute

Precarious, for no ooner fate demands
The parent tock, than (pious ympathy!)
Revolts th' adopted noe.—Such ills attend
Obcene and bought embraces. Wier thou,
Find <> nymph, whom tender ympathy
Attracts to thee; while all her captives ele,
Aw'd by majetic beauty, mourn aloof

Dicreetly lavih'd. Sacrifice to her
The precious hours, nor grudge with uch a mate
The ummer's day to toy or winter's night.
Now clap with dying fondnes in your arms
Her yielding wait; now on her welling breat
Recline your cheek, with eager kies pres
Her balmy lips, and drinking from her eyes
Reitles love, the tender flame confes,
Ineffable but by the murm'ring voice
Of genuine joy; then hug, and kis again,
Stretch'd on the genial couch, while joyful glows
Thy manly pride, and throbbing with deire
Pants furious, felt through all th • obtacles
That intervene: but <…> fervid coure
Mountains nor eas oppoe, ca • oon remove
Barriers o light. Then, when her lovely limbs,
Oft lovely deem'd, far lovelier now beheld,
Thro' all your trembling joints increae the flame;
Forth with dicover to her dazzled ight
The tately novelty, and to her hand
Uher the new acquaintance. She perhaps,
A vere, will coldly chide, and half afraid,
<> , half pleas'd, the tumid wonder view
With neck retorted and oblique regard;
Nor quite her curious eye indulging, nor
Reframing quite. Perhaps when you attempt
The weet <> toyful he reits
With thy reluctance; nathles you purue;
The oft attack, and warmly puh the war,
Till quite o'erpow'r'd with love, the melting mai •
Faintly oppoes. On the brink at lat
Arriv'd of • iddy rapture, plunge not in
Precipitant, but pare a virgin's pain;
Ah! pare a gentle virgin! pare yourelf!
Let anguine war love • tender rites profane

Reciprocal. Nor droop becaue the door
Of blis eems hut and barricadoed trong;
But triumph rather in this faithful pledge
Of innocence and fair virginity
Inviolate. And hence the ubtle wench,
Her •• iden honours torn, in evil hour

Unee ••
• orn, and hrunk her virgin roe;
Studious • ow bet the guilty wound to heal,
Her han • bet palliate with fair outward hew,

Inward le ••
<> , with painful hand collects
The ylvan <> . The lover Myrtle yields
Her typtic <> , and the horrid Thorn
Its prune aute •• , in vain the Caper hides
It's wand'ring • ots; the mighty Oak himelf,
Sole tyrant of the hade, that long had 'cap'd
The tanner's rage, poil'd of his callous rhind,
Stands bleak and bare. Thee, and a thouand more
Of humbler growth and far inferior name,
Bitort, and Dock, and that way-faring herb

Beware of thoe, for is our dang'rous days

Concerns, And here expect no dye of wound:
No wound is made; the •• rrugated parts,

Not wrinkled into frowns when genuine mot)
Relape apace, and quit their borrow'd tone,
Yet judge with charity the varied work
Of nature's hand, Perhaps the purple tream,
Emollient bath, leaves flexible, and lax
The part i • lately wah'd But haples he,
In nuptial night, on whom a horrid cham
Yawns dreadful, wate and wild; like that thro' which
The wand'ring Greek, and Cytherea's Son,
Diving, explor'd hell's, adamantine gates:
An uneential void; where neither love
Nor pleaure dwells, where warm creation dies
Starv'd in th' abortive gulph; the dire effects
Of ue too frequent, or for love or gold.
Now hear me, lovers! ye whoe roving hearts
No acred nuptial chains have yet confin'd;
Attentive hear, and daily, nightly weigh
The counels age, which thro' my raptur'd breat,
To you th' aupicious heav'nly mue conveys:
The mue, no oothing miniter of vice;
Tho' now in portive vein to youthful ears
She tunes her ong, to give intruction grace.
Attend, ye wie! no frantic Bacchanal,
No hameles bard of the licentious rout
Of fluh'd Silenus, ings.—What nature bids
Is good, is wie; and faultles we obey.
We mut obey, howe'er hard toick dreams
Of apathy, much vaunted, eldom prov'd:
For oft beneath the philoophic gloom
Sly Lewdnes lurks, and oft'ner mazy Guile,
That with well-mimick'd love th' unwary heart
Lures to its fate, and hails while it betrays!
There bloated Pride too dwells, and baneful Hate,
And dark Revenge, than which a deadlier fiend
Ne'er pour'd its venom through a human breat;
Far hence be thee; we know great Nature's pow'r.
Mother of things, whoe vat unbounded way
From the deep centre all around extends
Wide to the flaming barriers of the world.
We feel her pow'r: we trive not to repres
(Vainly repres'd, or to deformity)
Her lawful growth: ours be the tak alone
To check her rude excrecences; to prune
Her wanton overgrowth, and where the ports
In hapes too wild, to lead her gently back,
With prudent hand, to better form and ue
For wiet ends this univeral power
Gave appetites; from whoe quick impule life
Subits; by which we only live; all life
Inipid ele, unactive, unenjoy'd.
Hence too this peopled earth; which, that extinct,
That flame for propagation, oon would roll
A lifeles mas, and vainly cumber heav'n.
Then love of pleaure ways each heart, and we
From that no more than from ourelves can fly.
Blameles when govern'd well. But where it errs,
Extravagant, and wildly leads to ill,
Public or private; there its curbing pow'r
Cool reaon mut exert.—This leon weigh,
Ye tender pairs, Indulge your gentle flames,
Each fondet wih, and bathe your ouls in love.
But let dicretion guard the life of blis,
Virtuous in pleaure. So you hall enjoy
Pleaure unmix'd, and without thorn the roe.
This caution corn'd beware th' event pervere:
Expect, for pleaure, pain and harp remore;
For love, averion and each broken vow,
The j • t of fools, the pity of the wie.
Be ecret lovers, Let no dang'rous py
Catch your oft glances; as oblique they deal
Mutual contagion, darting all the oul
In miive love; nor hear your lab'ring ighs.
But chiefly when the high-wrought rapture calls,
Impatient, to oft deeds, then, then retire
From every mortal •• n. The Sapient King
(Whoe loves who could defame?) in the mild gloom,
Deep in the centre of his gardens, hid,
Held dalliance with his fair Egyptian poue,
Find then ome oft obcure retreat, untrod
By mortals ele. where thick-embow'ring hades
Condene to darknes and embrown the day;
There, afe from all profane acces purue
Love's bahful rites. For oft the curious eye
Of prying childhood, and th' apect malign,
Wanting and wan, of virgin tale in years,
Shed baneful influence on the rites of love.
And thou, my on, when floods of mellowing wine
And ocial joys have looen'd all thy breat
When every ecret guhes; this at leat,
This one reerve, of love and bounteous charms
Of truting beauty; vent'ring all for thee,
For thy delight her fortune and her fame;
For her thou nothing. Hold! ingrateful, hold
Thy wanton tongue! Leave to the lat of fools,
Of villains! that ungen'rous vanity,
Cruel and bae, to vaunt of ecret joys;
Of joys on thee, o vaunting, ill betow'd,
O dare not thus with mortal ting to wound
The tender haples ex! Does thy vile breath
So blat my iter's or my daughter's fame,—
By Heav'n thou diet! thy treach'rous blood alone
Can wah my honour clean. Prudent, meantime,
Ye gen'rous maids, revenge your ex's wrong;
Let not the mean detroyer e'er approach
Your acred charms. Now muter all your pride,
Contempt, and corn, that, hot from beauty's eye,
Confounds the mighty impudent, and mites
The front unknown to hame, Trut not his vows,
His labour'd ighs, and well-diembled tears,
Nor well the triumph of known perjury.
Meanwhile, my on, if angry fate, or love
Grown indicreet, or loud Lucina, tell
Th' important ecret: is thy mate well form'd,
Virtuous, and equal for thy lawful bed,
Save her, I charge thee, from foul infamy,
And lonely hame; let wedlock's holy tie
Legitimate th' indioluble flames.
If abject birth, dihonourable, and mind
Incultivate or vicious, to that height
Forbid her hopes to climb; at leat ecure
From penury her humble tate, by thee,
Ele humbled more, and to neceity,
Stern foe to Virtue, Fame, and Life betray'd,
A helples prey. O! let no parent's woe,
No plaints of truting innocence, nor tears
Of pining beauty, blat thy guilty joys.
Shall he, o late the oft'ner of thy life,
Thy chief delight, whoe melting eence oft
Lay with thy melting eence kindly mix'd
(As far as bodies and embodied ouls
Can mingle); he who deem'd thy vows incere,
Thy paion more than elfih, and thy love
To her devoted, as was her's to thee;
Shall he (O! cruel perfidy!) at lat,
When with her tainted name the winds grow ick,
When envious prudery chides, affecting corn
Of nat'ral joys, and they of public fame.
Inulting, hail her iter; while each friend
Diguted flies: hall he not find in thee
Unhaken amity? when to thy arms,
Well-known, with wonted confidence he flies,
To pour her orrows forth, and forth her cares,
Shall he then find thy faithles heart from home,
From her etrang'd? at that diat'rous hour
Wilt thou ungently purn her from thy love?
To wate in ickly grief her once-priz'd charms,
Forlorn to languih out her life, to lead
Depis'd, unwedded, her dihonour'd days?
Or, if her barren fortune, hard like thee,
Scowls meagre Want (whoe iron empire Pride,
Reluctant, and her offspring Modety,
Bluhing at lat obey) unkill'd in arts
Of mercenary Venus, to increae
The rompih band, that, without pleaure lewd,
With deep-felt orrow gay, through Trivia's reign
Nightly olicit lovers; oft repuls'd,
Oft when invited to the barren toil
Thankles deerted by their lipp'ry loves!
Or to the alt of years, where tedious lut
Uncouth and montrous creeps through freezing loins,
Patient ubmitted! to the boit'rous will
Of midnight ruffians! to abhorr'd dieae,
Hourly expos'd, and Draco's fiercer rage!
Spare, mighty Draco! pare a haples race,
By their own ex to wretchednes betray'd.
A woman bore thee; by each tender name
Of woman pare! hat thou or daughter fair,
Or iter? they, but for a happier birth,
The gift of fate, and honour's guardian, Pride
Early inpir'd, had well'd the common tream.
While he whom now thy awful name dimays,
Portentous heard from far, with fortune's miles
And fair example, might have grac'd thy bed,
A virtuous mate, in ev'ry charm complete.
A pious duty next, neglected oft,
Demands my ong, If from thy ecret b • d
Of luxury unbidden offspring rie
Let them be kindly welcom'd to the day.
'Tis nature bids, To nature's acred voice
Attend; and from the monter-breeding deep,
The ravag'd air, and howling wildernes,
Learn parent virtues, Shall the growling bear
Be more a fire than thou? an infant once,
Helples and weak, but for paternal care,
Thou hadt not liv'd to propagate a race
To mis'ry, to reign to tep-dame fate
Perhaps a worthier offspring than thy • i • e
Tenderly rear'd. For from the tol'n embrace,
Untir'd with worn acquaintance, keenly urg'd,
Elate with gen'rous rapture, likeliet prings
The noblet breed, mot animated, bet.
What he •• es hence have iued! what fam'd chiefs!
And demi-gods, of old! the tealth of love
Gave Greece her Hercules, and mighty Rome

Firt roe beneath <>
••• dom on of Mars.
Thy vigour too, the bloom of thy trength,
Reckles and wild profus'd, in dang'rous days,
Or in the enate wie, and nobly warm
To public good, may ave the ruhing tate;
Or, bold in arms, may roll her thunders forth
To hatter ditant kies, and, rous'd to blood,
Uher the Britih Lion to the field.
Thy country claims thy care; nure well her hopes,
And thine; nor thou her church's hungry wolves,
Hight Overeers, with thy own children's gore
Satiate, if rapine know atiety.
For bred to death, and of agacious noe,
A prowling herd, lur'd with the recent mell
Of ecret birth, their carnage weet, or led
By infant wailings, querulous and hrill,
Beet thy frighted gates. Thee timely thou
Prevent, or mourn too late thy ravih'd gold
And captive on; to the treet-dunning tribe
Of mendicants let out, fictitious badge
Of low ditres: there to what life of pain
Led up who knows? to what digraceful fate,
What gibbet, bred? or from his parent's arms,
With nure unpitying, unbenign, exil'd
To qualid lodge, to find in Famine's cave
A ling'ring death; or by a deadlier hag,
Than her that rides the lab'ring night oppres'd,
Untimely ink beneath a heavier fate.
While they, the ons of licens'd rapine, creen'd
Under the altar of the God of life
With murder tain'd, on what hould raie thy on
Nightly regale, carnivorous; for them
The heifer bleeds, or for her laughter'd young
Roams wild the woodland bounds; and what hould now
To thy young hopes run oft in balmy rills
Lacteous, to them in deep Oporto flows,
Or hot Madeira. Thus the anguine feat
They crown, nor dread the cry of infant blood.
Thee precepts wiely keep, by thee direct
Thy teps through pleaure's labyrinth. Unhurt
And unoffending, thus thy tutor'd feet
May tread the wilds of ele deluive joy.
So hall no orrows wound; no ruder cares
Diturb thy pleaures, no remoreful tears
Attend thy gay delight; nor ighs make way,
But uch as heave the pleaure-burden'd breat,
As utter love, with peechles eloquence
Well undertood; and breathe from oul to oul
The oft infection, fondly till receiv'd.
Almighty Love! O unexhauted ource
Of univeral joy! firt principle
Of nature all-creating! harmony,
By which her mighty movements all are rul'd!
Soft tyrant of each element, whoe way
Reitles, thro' the wilds of air is felt,
Thro' earth, and the deep empire of the main!
Thy willing laves, we own thy gentle pow'r,
In us upreme, with kind endearments rais'd
Above the merely enual touch of brutes.
By thy oft charm the avage breat is tam'd,
The genius rais'd. The heav'nly warmth inpires
Whate'er is noble, gen'rous, or humane,
Or elegant; whate'er adorns the mind,
Graces or weetens life; and without thee,
Nothing or gay or amiable appears.
Yet not to Love (thus polihing the oul,
Thus charming; tho' of every finer breat
The ov'reign joy), yet not to Love alone
Yield languid all your hours. The elf-ame cates
Still offer'd, oon the appetite offend;
The mot delicious oonet. Other joys,
Other puruit, their equal hare demand
Of cultivation, Thee with kindly change
Will cheer your weetly-varied days; from thee
With quicker ene you hall and firmer nerves
Return to Love, when Love again invites.
Be thoe the leat neglected which inform
With virtue, ene, and elegance, the mind:
Thoe what before was amiable improve,
And lend to Love new grace and dignity.
Life too has erious cares, which madly corn'd,
The means of pleaure melt.—And age will come,
When Love, alas! the flow'r of human joys,
Mut hrink, in horrid frot. O haples he!
Thrice haples then! whoe only joy was that;
Whoe young deires tumultuous till engage
To wield a load of unobedient limbs,
With vain attempt. Him th' inclement pow'r
Of craving impotence, to fonder toys
Than other dotage knows, or eay-dup'd
Credulity can well believe, incites,
Him all the Nymphs depie, and the young Loves
With leering corn behold; while vig'rous beat
Has • led his haken limbs, urviving till
In his green fancy. Thence what dep'rate toil
By flagellation, and the rage of blows,
To roue the Venus loitering in his veins!
Fruitles, for Venus unolicited
The kindet miles, abhorring painful rites.
Ceae, rev'rend fathers! from thoe youthful ports
Retire, before unfinih'd feats betray
Your lacken'd nerves, The hoary years, deign'd
For widom, for edate philoophy,
And contemplation, ill agree with love.
Cheerful retire: nor grudge in peevih aws,
Like envious monitors, the prightly joys
Of luty youth. You had your genial time
Of pleaure;—ours is on the rapid wing!
And you whoe youthful blood impetuous rolls,
With gen'rous pirits fraught and kindly balm,
Huband your vigour well; if aught or health,
Or offspring num'rous, beautiful, and trong,
Or pleaure weigh. For from the trite embrace
Follow faint relaxation, trength impair'd.
Digut, and mutual apathy, Love's bane.
Some boat, I know, their vigour to renew,
And keen deire, by food retorative,
Or pharmacy more noxious. Orchis hence,
Lacivious bulb, Satyrion better nam'd;
And that maritime, which the ea-born Queen
Feeds with her native pume, Eryngo, mild;

l.U: am'd among the fungous tribe;

lg.l: And fell Cantharides; in various forms
Are us'd. But what enues? Dieaes more
Then ever burden'd Auter's drooping wings,
Cold Tremors, Spams, and Cephal • as dire
Eternal flux of nature's balmy dew,
Tabes, and gaunt Maramus, hideous los
Of godlike reaon, and th' imprion'd rage
Of fierce Lipyria, whoe collected fires
The vitals only eize. Or if the ons
Of jaded luxury thoe plagues ecape,
They wate their melting youth, and bring grey hairs
Before their time, grey hairs and idle years.
Leave Nature to herelf, not covet more
Than Nature gives, that but to real wants
Each well-conducted appetite provokes.
But chiefly thee, fair nymph. behoves to know
That love and joy, when in their prime, mut fear
Decay, <> of all created things,
Be frugal then; the coyly-yielded kis
Charms mot, and gives the mot incere delight.
Cheapnes offends; hence on the harlot's lip
No rapture hangs, however fair he eem,
However form'd for love and am'rous play.
Hail Modety! fair female honour hail!
Beauty's chief ornament, without whoe charm
Beauty diguts; or gives but vulgar joys.
Its balmy eence weet! and, but for thee,
The very raptures of the lawful bed
Were outrage and foul riot, rites obcene!
Celetial maid! be it lawful that with lips
Profane I name thee, and in wanton ong.
But in thee vicious days great Nature's laws
Are purn'd; eternal Virtue, which nor time
Nor place can change, nor cutom changing all.
Is mock'd to corn; and lewd Abue intead,
Daughter of night, her hameles revels holds
O'er half the globe, while the chate face of day
Eclipes at her rites. For man with man,
And man with woman (montrous to relate!)
Leaving the nat'ral road themelves debae
With deeds uneemly, and dihonour foul.
Britons, for hame! be male and female till,
Banih this foreign vice; it grows not here;
It dies neglected; and in clime o chate
Cannot but by forc'd cultivation thrive:
So cultivated wells the more our hame,
The more our guilt. And hall not greater guilt
Meet greater punihment and heavier doom:
Not lighter for delay. Did Jutice pare
The men of Sodom ert? like us they inn'd,
Like us they ought the paths of montrous joy;
Till, urg'd to wrath at lat, all-patient Heav'n
Decending wrapt them in ulphureous torm,
And where proud palaces appear'd, the haunts
Of luxury, now leeps a ullen pool;
Vengeful memorial of Almighty ire,
Againt the ons of lewdnes, exercis'd!

div.trailer: END OF THE OECONOMY OF LOVE.

lg.l: IF beauty's vaunt demands a wretch's pain,
And tortur'd victims ooth thy high didain;
Come, while thou mayt, thy lover's pangs deride;
The uff'rer oon hall mock thy corn and pride.
The darkling purpoe labours in my breat;
Some pirit whipers, I hall be at ret.—
—From thee wild eye-balls not a tear hall flow,
My frantic grief hall learn to laugh at woe,
When reaon from her orb of rule is thrown;
And bold depair explores the realms unknown.
What phantoms rie!—pare, pare, ye hideous band!
Heav'n, heav'n, retrain a wretch's impious hand!—
—A thouand furies flap their murky wings,
They goad my madding oul with corpion tings.—
Les dire the train, that roe at Juno's call,
While able gore bedew'd the regal hall.
Round 1 no's head, the Stygian brand they hurl'd.
In venom'd folds, their hiing nakes they curl'd;
The Theban's oul receiv'd th' infernal brood.—
—He rag'd, he thirted for his children's blood.
With cheerles gaze, I mark the dawning light;
The un decends, I cure the gloom of night;
Friends, bus'nes, books I loath;—my ullen fate,
My frantic love, but mot myelf, I hate.
What aving aim! my feeble pray'rs arie;
But feeble pray'rs mut never reach the kies.—
What gifts of heav'n! with bounteous heav'n at trife,
My love embitters all the goods of life.
Oh fond remembrance! wakeful cruel guet,
The toil, the torments of th' enamour'd breat.—
—Alas, I lov'd thee, ere I view'd thy charms,—
And curt th • youth, that Clara's beauty prais'd,
'Twas wonder firt the gay decription rais'd,
The heav'nly theme had touch'd his lips with fire.
He pake, and wonder often'd to deire.
Poet, inpir'd, on ev'ry charm he dwelt,
From pore to pore the ubtle flames I felt;
I ran—I flew—I view'd. in evil hour,
The boat the darling of creative pow'r.
Better, dieae had chain'd me to my bed.
Or vollied lightning rank'd me with the dead.—
From ev'ry mile, the glad allurements tray'd.
In ev'ry glance, the oftet wihes play'd
Who there could read, the deep capricious art,
The portive hardnes of thy cruel heart?
Who then the pangs?—alas, alas, 'tw • re vain,—
Tho' hell had <> , athwart my dep'rate way.
And tarting fiends recoil'd from udden day.
Soon, with my peace th' inulting wanton pray'd;
With fatal kill, th' uncertain reins he way'd.
Now floating looe, they wave their eay folds,
And now evere, the teely curb he holds.
Skill'd to torment, and tudious to detroy.
With floods of woe he blends a drop of joy.
Now (like the dove) familiar, oft, and bland,
Uncall'd he comes, and courts the fondling hand.
Now (like th' imperial eagle) eeks the kies,
Sublimely tow'rs, and mocks my dazzled eyes.
Now gently kind the various maid appears,
In oothing miles array'd and balmy <>
Mild as the • lphids of the gliding <>
Mild as the phantoms of the maiden's dream.
And now he takes th' avenging pirits form;
Array'd in flames, and burting in the torm:
Midt the wild havock good and blameles till,
For ruin bright, and beautiful to kill.
Well knows my tyrant, that unvaried pain,
Might looe her captive from the weary chain.
She corns the <> , yet loves th' applauding rhyme •
Her <> , <> , pride would <> in other time •
Thouands; he ees are noble, wie and brave,
Th' enamour'd poet is no vulgar lave;
And mine th' applaue that pride herelf might chue;
The mue of Edwin is no common mue.
Severely chate. he walks erect and bold,
Not poorly barter'd, nor at random giv'n.
Her praie is hoarded for th' elect of heav'n.
O friend of man! O lat and dread repoe!
Dear acred harbour from the torm of woes.—
O when hall death—Alas! I vainly rave—
Sure I hall love thee ev'n beyond the grave.
From pangs to pangs the weary pirit cat,
Midt changeful woes may find its paion lat.
Deluded wretch, no more purue the flame
That draws thee wide from ev'ry noble aim,
Blats thy fair hopes, and vain exitence fills
With dreams of good, and certainty of ills.—
Where now the gen'rous toils that warm'd thy youth?
The path of cience, and the light of truth?—
O hame of manhood!—Reaon wakes my oul.—
I tear thy chains, I purn thy bae controul.
That heav'nly mile!—my fondly changeful mind!
What hope would whiper—Clara may be kind.
Deluded novice!—poor believing child!—
The fondet wretch that woman e'er beguil'd!—
Behold the creature of thy high command,
The pliant wax beneath thy forming hand;
No more, my Clara, hall thy lave rebel,
No more complaints, my vain depair farewel;
The tar of Venus in th' acendant tow'rs.
There Clara its, and guides the miling hours;
With peace and love he fills the gladome phere,
And riing good and beaming hopes are there.
Strange pow'r of woman! with what high controul
A mile or glance can take the prion'd oul,
And hurl it far from reaon and from ret;
Or tos it like a loaf within the breat!

div.head: DESPAIR.
div.byline: Tranlated from the French of Tritan. BY THE SAME.

lg.l: MY fruitles love, with many a lavih'd ong.
And altars, grac'd thee midt th' immortal throng;
Ungrateful maid! neglected and forlorn,
I tand the mark for all thy hafts of corn;
Ungrateful maid, thy fierce contempt deplore,
With ighs of living flame, and tears of treaming gore.
When my fond numbers would conceal her hate,
And natch her beauties from oblivious fate,
From pole to pole when Clara's praies ound,
Ungrateful maid! he mocks the am'rous wound.
Her ingle word a healing balm might how'r,
Yet he that word withholds, and vaunts her cruel pow'r.
Dear galling yoke, which I mut never rend!
Dear cruel maid, whom pray'rs mut never bend!
By one lat blow, my hand, fulfil her doom,
And ret, my orrows, in eternal gloom!
Thou wretch, at once thy chains and life reign;
With courage worthy love, and worthy charms divine.
Tremendous pow'r, thou demon pale deform,
Who ne'er art call'd, but when the gather'd torm
O'er life is pread, nor hope remains below,
Depair, I call thee to relieve my woe!
O come, thy kindly cruel aid impart:
Teach me to heal the pangs that gnaw my burting heart.
Come, ghatly phantom, with thy direful band.
Come, guide the troke with unrelenting hand.
O bring me peace, and cloe my weary days,
<> pomp of death my ettled woe dimays.
Since Clara's eyes withdraw their cheering light,
The genial beams of heav'n but pain my aching ight.
I ee thee come with horror in thy train,
Affliction, phrenzy, rage, depair, and pain;
Devouring flames and words around are een,
The baneful aconire, and poniard keen.
That et ad Pyramus from anguih free,
And gave to Caro's oul its darling liberty.
A bloody torrent <> thy path along,
• ell fell depite is there, and giant wrong,
That angry heav'n defy, and fortune's hate;—
I ee the pangs for me reerv'd by fate,
And hame the wrath the ling'ring purpoe chide,
"O fly, thou wretch, from life, nor future woes abide."
Yes, I will die, to g •• d thy avage heart.—
Receive the <> of thy cruel art.—
Yes, thou <> ee,—no longer mock my pain,—
I burt the prion of thy <> didain.
When pity <> to balm the lover's wound,
The ret of death remains, and poion may be found.—
